name: Ralph Lauren
title: New York Times reporter pitched Epstein interview on 'your terms' - Al Jazeera
description:
“I know this is tough and hard for you, but remember jail may [be] bad, but it is not forever,” Thomas wrote.
As part of his pitch to Epstein, Thomas recalled a 2002 profile he wrote about the financier for New York Magazine, titled Jeffrey Epstein: International Moneyman of Mystery.
That is no longer the case after all this,” Thomas wrote to Epstein.
Again to focus on the business and scientific/philanthropic aspect of the piece,” Thomas wrote.
“He seems very interested in your relationship with the news media,” Thomas wrote to Epstein in an email dated June 1, 2016.
text:
A New York Times reporter told Jeffrey Epstein that he could write an article that would define the financier on his own terms as he faced allegations of sexually abusing minors in the months leading up to his 2008 conviction, newly uncovered emails reveal.

After a negative article about Epstein was published in September 2007, then-New York Times journalist Landon Thomas Jr advised Epstein to “get ahead” of more bad publicity by doing an interview that would define the story “on your terms”.

Recommended Stories

list of 4 items

list 1 of 4Thai soldier, four Cambodian civilians killed as border tensions reignite

list 2 of 4Nigeria says it deployed jets, troops to Benin to ‘dislodge coup plotters’

list 3 of 4US lawmakers urge release of video of double-tap boat strike in Caribbean

list 4 of 4Nigeria rescues 100 children abducted from Catholic boarding school

end of list

“I Just read the Post. Now the floodgates will open — you can expect Vanity Fair and NYMag to pile on,” Thomas wrote to Epstein in an email dated September 20, 2007, referring to the magazines Vanity Fair and New York Magazine.

“My view is that the quicker you get out ahead of this and define the story and who you are on your terms in the NYT, the better it will be for you.”

Thomas, who left the Times in 2019, urged Epstein to quickly do an interview to prevent the “popular tabloid perception” about him from hardening, and expressed sympathy over his legal troubles.

“I know this is tough and hard for you, but remember jail may [be] bad, but it is not forever,” Thomas wrote.

As part of his pitch to Epstein, Thomas recalled a 2002 profile he wrote about the financier for New York Magazine, titled Jeffrey Epstein: International Moneyman of Mystery.

Written before Epstein’s first arrest in 2006, the profile portrayed the financier as an enigmatic but highly successful businessman with the appearance of a “taller, younger Ralph Lauren” and a “relentless brain that challenges Nobel Prize-winning scientists”.

The piece contained glowing appraisals from Epstein’s many high-profile associates, whose praise-filled descriptions included that he was “very smart”, “amazing”, “extraordinary”, and “talented”.

“Remember how for a while my NY Mag piece was the defining piece on you? That is no longer the case after all this,” Thomas wrote to Epstein.

“But I think if we did a piece for the Times, with the documents and evidence that you mention, plus you speaking for the record, we can again have a story that becomes the last public word on Jeffrey Epstein.”

A little more than a week later, on September 28, Thomas sent Epstein an email reiterating the importance of “getting out ahead” of other publications.

Thomas suggested that he begin reaching out to associates of Epstein who could talk about the financier’s business activities and scientific and philanthropic work, including former Harvard President Larry Summers and Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak.

“Before I get a glimpse of the legal material, I was thinking that I should at least start calling around to people who know you. Again to focus on the business and scientific/philanthropic aspect of the piece,” Thomas wrote.

“Could I start to do that — call people like Larry Summers, Jess Staley, George Mitchell, Ehud Barak, Bill Richardson and others?” Thomas finished the email expressing his hope that Epstein was “holding up okay” and stating his view that “we need to move on this.”

It is not clear how Epstein responded to Thomas’s emails, which were included in a trove of emails from Epstein’s personal accounts that were made available to Al Jazeera by the whistleblower website Distributed Denial of Secrets.

Thomas did not respond to a request for comment.

Following Thomas’s correspondence with Epstein, the Times went on to publish an article by the journalist detailing the financier’s downfall the following year.

The article, published a day after Epstein’s guilty plea on June 30, 2008, drew from in-person and phone interviews that Thomas had conducted with the financier, including during a visit to Epstein’s island of Little St James several months earlier.

In the article, Thomas described the financier sitting on the patio of his island mansion as he likened himself to the eponymous character of the satirical novel Gulliver’s Travels.

“Gulliver’s playfulness had unintended consequences,” Epstein was quoted as saying.

“That is what happens with wealth. There are unexpected burdens as well as benefits.”

A 2019 report by NPR said colleagues of Thomas at the Times had been “appalled” by the article when they reviewed it years later, following the journalist’s admission that he had solicited a $30,000 donation from Epstein for a cultural centre.

The emails obtained by Al Jazeera also show that Epstein emailed an error-strewn Word document to himself in which Thomas is described discussing the legal case against Epstein with then-Florida prosecutor David Weinstein.

The purpose and origin of the document, which describes Thomas and Weinstein discussing technical aspects of the charges facing Epstein, is unclear. Weinstein said he spoke to Thomas in January 2008, but that the document did not contain an accurate description of their conversation.

Weinstein said they had spoken about the “criminal justice process and general state and federal statutes”, but not Epstein’s case specifically.

He said he did not know where the information in the document came from or who provided it to Epstein.

“I never spoke with him about the specific facts of the late Mr Epstein’s case, nor did I offer any opinion about that matter,” Weinstein told Al Jazeera.

The emergence of the emails between Thomas and Epstein comes after correspondence the two men shared from 2015 to 2018 came to light last month in a batch of documents released by US lawmakers.

Among other revelations, those emails showed that Thomas let Epstein know that the late investigative journalist John Connolly had contacted him for information for Connolly’s 2016 book Filthy Rich: The Jeffrey Epstein Story.

“He seems very interested in your relationship with the news media,” Thomas wrote to Epstein in an email dated June 1, 2016. “I told him you were a hell of a guy :)”.

A spokesperson for the Times said Thomas had not worked for the newspaper since early 2019 “after editors discovered his failure to abide by our ethical standards”.

name: Uber
title: Uber Pioneers First Fully Electric Zero-Emissions Ferry in London - The Maritime Executive
description:
Ferry transport in London is entering a new phase, focusing on sustainability following the launch of a zero-emission vessel.
Four years after committing to introducing high-speed and eco-friendly vessels to operate on the Thames, Uber Boat by Thames Clippers is launching Orbit Clipper, the UK’s first fully electric zero-emissions ferry.
Uber Boat by Thames Clippers reckons that the Orbit Clipper is a groundbreaking vessel in many aspects.
The 25-meter (82-foot) vessel with a maximum speed of 12 knots forms a major component of Uber Boat by Thames Clippers drive towards sustainable transport in London.
“The launch of Orbit Clipper is a significant milestone for sustainable transport in London.
text:
Ferry transport in London is entering a new phase, focusing on sustainability following the launch of a zero-emission vessel. The boat is being promoted as transforming the experience of passengers travelling along the Thames.

Four years after committing to introducing high-speed and eco-friendly vessels to operate on the Thames, Uber Boat by Thames Clippers is launching Orbit Clipper, the UK’s first fully electric zero-emissions ferry. On December 5, the new vessel completed its first passenger trip on the Thames, ushering in what is being described as a new era for sustainable transport in London.

Uber Boat by Thames Clippers reckons that the Orbit Clipper is a groundbreaking vessel in many aspects. The 150-passenger ferry with capacity for 100 bicycles features a roll-on/roll-off design that enables automated docking on both sides owing to its double-ended, self-docking, auto-mooring features. The vessel will operate between London’s Canary Wharf on the north side of the Thames and Rotherhithe on the south, offering an efficient and eco-friendly service for cross-river transport.

Built by UK’s Wight Shipyard Co, Orbit Clipper was partly funded by the UK government through the Department for Transport and Innovate UK. The 25-meter (82-foot) vessel with a maximum speed of 12 knots forms a major component of Uber Boat by Thames Clippers drive towards sustainable transport in London.

In recent years, the operator has added three hybrid high-speed vessels to its main fleet of River Buses, each cutting emissions by up to 90 percent and contributing to its ambitious target of reducing carbon emissions by 50 percent by 2035 and achieving net-zero by 2050. The boats operate on battery power while in Central London and recharge while using biofueled power on the rest of their journey.

“The launch of Orbit Clipper is a significant milestone for sustainable transport in London. As the UK’s first all-electric, zero-emissions vessel, it represents our commitment to reducing the city’s carbon footprint while continuing to provide reliable and efficient river transport,” said Sean Collins, Uber Boat by Thames Clippers CEO.

The new vessel is expected to replace the current cross-river ferry service, continuing to serve the growing number of passengers. Estimates indicate the vessel will, on average, ferry more than 20,000 passengers daily.

name: Best Buy
title: Microsoft Surface Pro 12‑inch AI laptop Christmas deal | Windows Central
description:
Holiday discounts on highly-wishlisted laptops are starting to ramp up as we draw closer to Christmas Day, like the Microsoft Surface Pro 12-inch, for instance.
So if you had to choose between the two, I'd recommend the Surface Pro 12-inch for those seeking the best portable laptop experience.

Is the Surface Pro 12-inch an ARM-based PC, and do normal apps work?
The Surface Pro 12-inch features two USB-C 3.2 ports and supports 45W chargers for fast charging.
text:
Holiday discounts on highly-wishlisted laptops are starting to ramp up as we draw closer to Christmas Day, like the Microsoft Surface Pro 12-inch, for instance.

This wonderful piece of hardware, which we consider one of 2025's best laptops for its performance, keyboard responsiveness, and portability, among other rich features, is now on a holiday discount for $549.99 at Best Buy.

Why buy the Surface Pro 12-inch?

The Microsoft Surface Pro 12-inch is a well-designed laptop packed with plenty of features that make it worth buying for hard-working students or professionals looking to get their work done in the office or while travelling abroad.

Its performance is rock-solid thanks to its Qualcomm Snapdragon X Plus processor, which is able run Microsoft Office apps, edit digital art in Photoshop, and search through internet browsers with ease. Not to mention it does so without generating too much heat in the system or draining its batteries.

It also features a responsive keyboard that instantly reads your key inputs, high-quality audio speakers and camera, and a gorgeous 12-inch touchscreen display able to render images with crisp details at 2196x1464 resolution and 90Hz refresh rates.

The touchscreen is also compatible with stylus pens, so you can draw digital art with greater ease compared to using a mouse.

The Surface Pro 12-inch is also portable-friendly as it measures at 274 x 190 x 7.8 mm (10.79" x 7.48" x 0.31") and weighs around 0.68 kg (1.5 lbs), so you can store it easily in luggage/carrying cases without requiring much strength to lug it around.

On top of that, it has full Copilot+ AI integration with a mighty Qualcomm NPU of 45 TOPS, so it can efficiently run AI-empowered features like Click To Do, Recall, and Studio Effects.

The only drawbacks of this laptop are that it has a short battery life of 7 hours when its Power Settings are in 'Best Efficiency' Mode or 5 hours when it's on 'Balanced' Mode.

Not to mention its display's colors could use some work as they're often muted even when running on the 'enhanced' color profile.

Lastly, this laptop can run a hefty MSRP of $799 at most retailers. Thankfully, that last bugbear is no longer an issue for a limited time as it's now on sale for $549.99 at Best Buy.

So, if you're looking for a new workhorse laptop to tackle the challenges of 2026, then this Christmas bargain for the Surface Pro 12-inch is for you.

Alternative discounts

If stock runs out for the Surface Pro 12-inch with (256GB UFS) runs dry at Best Buy, or if you have budget for more storage, here are some alternative discounts as backup options:

$699.99 at Best Buy (was $899.99) (512GB UFS)

$749.00 at Walmart (was $799.99) (256GB UFS)

Competition

Some would argue that there are better devices than the Surface Pro 12-inch out there that offer better value and performance.

One such tablet that it gets compared to is the Apple iPad Air M3, which offers more display size options (11" and 13"), more color options, a superior "tablet" experience, and a cheaper MSRP (especially the 11" version is on sale for $499.00 at Best Buy).

However, the Surface Pro 12-inch offers superior performance as an AI Laptop with its Snapdragon X Plus CPU, 45 TOPS NPU with full Copilot+ integration, 16GB of RAM, and Dual external display support.

So if you had to choose between the two, I'd recommend the Surface Pro 12-inch for those seeking the best portable laptop experience. At the same time, the Apple iPad Air M3 is better suited for those looking for a budget-friendly tablet experience.

FAQ

What is an NPU and how is it important for this laptop?

An NPU (Neural Processing Unit) is a microprocessor designed to improve an AI's capability of performing work efficiently. So, a laptop NPU with higher TOPS (Tera Operations Per Second), the easier an AI will handle workloads.

Can the Surface Pro 12-inch overheat?

It can warm while put under extreme workloads or charging. However, the Surface Pro 12-inch will automatically shut down if it exceeds its maximum operational temperature limit to prevent damage.

Is the Surface Pro 12-inch an ARM-based PC, and do normal apps work?

As it features a Qualcomm Snapdragon X Plus processor, the Surface Pro 12-inch is a Windows-on-Arm PC, capable of running normal compatible apps natively or a powerful new emulation technology called Prism, especially after Prism's latest update.

What are the Surface Pro 12-inch's ports and charging like?

The Surface Pro 12-inch features two USB-C 3.2 ports and supports 45W chargers for fast charging.

Neon is expected to announce a new chief marketing officer in the coming weeks.

Prior to Neon, Parkes worked at Alamo Drafthouse Cinemas and Drafthouse Films, rising from chief brand officer to chief marketing officer.
text:
Longtime Neon marketing chief Christian Parkes is stepping down from the indie studio, TheWrap has learned.

According to Variety, which first reported the news, Parkes resigned this week. Neon is expected to announce a new chief marketing officer in the coming weeks.

Parkes joined the company in 2017, a year after its founding. At Neon, he first gained attention with the campaign for “I, Tonya,” which earned Margot Robbie an Oscar nomination and won Allison Janney an Oscar for her performance as Tonya Harding’s mother.

He also worked on Neon campaigns for releases including “Anatomy of a Fall,” “Titane,” “Longlegs,” “The Seed of the Sacred Fig” and “Triangle of Sadness.” He most recently developed the promotional campaign for “Keeper,” an Osgood Perkins horror film that underperformed at the box office.

Prior to Neon, Parkes worked at Alamo Drafthouse Cinemas and Drafthouse Films, rising from chief brand officer to chief marketing officer. He previously worked at Nasty Gal, MySpace, Levi Strauss, Gatorade and Nike.

name: S&P Global
title: Sunset of US 45X tax credit makes some critical mineral projects unviable - S&P Global
description:
Critical mineral producers are struggling with project economics after President Donald Trump's budget reconciliation bill eliminated long-term certainty for the Section 45X advanced manufacturing tax credit, industry executives said at a Dec. 11 conference in Washington, DC.
The 45X credit provides up to 10% of production costs for US-based producers of critical minerals including cobalt, graphite, palladium and platinum — materials essential for renewable energy infrastructure, advanced electronics and defense systems.
Removing the 45X tax credit "was a huge hit to us," said Heather McDowell, senior vice president and general counsel for legal and external affairs, Americas, at Sibanye Stillwater Ltd. "Having that tax credit indefinitely is really what we expected."
Operational impacts Matthew Lengerich, president and executive general manager at Jervois Mining USA Ltd., said his company expanded its Finland project into the US specifically because of the 45X tax credit and other incentives.
"The project doesn't work without that tax credit," Lengerich said, highlighting the fundamental role the incentive played in making US critical mineral projects economically viable.
text:
Critical mineral producers are struggling with project economics after President Donald Trump's budget reconciliation bill eliminated long-term certainty for the Section 45X advanced manufacturing tax credit, industry executives said at a Dec. 11 conference in Washington, DC.

The sweeping legislation signed into law on July 4 phases out the credit starting in 2031 and eliminates it in 2034, removing what had been a permanent incentive under the Biden-era Inflation Reduction Act.

The change is forcing companies to reassess project viability and make difficult operational decisions as they compete with lower-cost foreign suppliers, particularly from China and Russia. The 45X credit provides up to 10% of production costs for US-based producers of critical minerals including cobalt, graphite, palladium and platinum — materials essential for renewable energy infrastructure, advanced electronics and defense systems.

Removing the 45X tax credit "was a huge hit to us," said Heather McDowell, senior vice president and general counsel for legal and external affairs, Americas, at Sibanye Stillwater Ltd. "Having that tax credit indefinitely is really what we expected."

The company, whose Montana operations include the only US-based palladium, platinum and rhodium mine, has cut approximately 40% of its workforce in recent months, McDowell said.

Operational impacts

Matthew Lengerich, president and executive general manager at Jervois Mining USA Ltd., said his company expanded its Finland project into the US specifically because of the 45X tax credit and other incentives. Jervois operates the only US-based cobalt mine in Idaho, though it has faced operational challenges due to price volatility.

"The project doesn't work without that tax credit," Lengerich said, highlighting the fundamental role the incentive played in making US critical mineral projects economically viable.

The discussion reflects broader challenges facing the US critical minerals sector as it attempts to reduce dependence on foreign suppliers while competing against state-subsidized operations. Price support mechanisms are a topic of increasing debate among business leaders and policymakers, with some arguing that Western projects cannot survive without effective government backing.

Earlier this year, the Department of Defense entered into a 10-year agreement with rare-earth producer MP Materials Corp. that guaranteed an offtake agreement at prices well above current market levels.

name: Nvidia
title: The AI darlings are slipping. That could be bad for Nvidia. - Axios
description:
Wall Street's AI hopium is turning to discernment, with investors punishing Oracle and Broadcom for less-than-stellar earnings this week, bringing Nvidia down alongside them.
Why it matters: It represents a shift in the AI investment thesis: Investors are set to reward efficiency, not spending, in 2026.
That could be a big problem for Nvidia, which benefits from record spending from a handful of Big Tech customers.
What they're saying: If 2026 is the year when investors reward efficient spending, "that certainly would be bad" for Nvidia, Mandeep Singh of Bloomberg Intelligence tells Axios.
"The market is discerning and telling you that Google is doing much better in capex efficiency than an Oracle," Singh says.
text:
Wall Street's AI hopium is turning to discernment, with investors punishing Oracle and Broadcom for less-than-stellar earnings this week, bringing Nvidia down alongside them.

Why it matters: It represents a shift in the AI investment thesis: Investors are set to reward efficiency, not spending, in 2026. That could be a big problem for Nvidia, which benefits from record spending from a handful of Big Tech customers.

What they're saying: If 2026 is the year when investors reward efficient spending, "that certainly would be bad" for Nvidia, Mandeep Singh of Bloomberg Intelligence tells Axios.

Oracle is seen as Exhibit A for inefficient spending within the AI elite class, while Google as seen as the North Star.

"The market is discerning and telling you that Google is doing much better in capex efficiency than an Oracle," Singh says.

Driving the news: In early afternoon trading on Friday, Oracle shares were down more than 4% after tumbling on Thursday, while Broadcom was down more than 10%. Nvidia shares were off nearly 2%.

Threat level: As executives see this turn in Wall Street's reward mechanism toward efficiency versus spending, they may shift to more budget-conscious models.

"If OpenAI and Oracle get scrutinized in terms of their investments, how does that affect Nvidia?" Singh says.

"To my mind, that's why Nvidia may remain under pressure."

By the numbers: With $90 billion in capex, Google was able to train Gemini 3, accelerate its cloud business and service generative AI into its search.

That capex represents a quarter of Google's revenue.

In contrast, Oracle reported a capex plan of $50 billion for the year. Its total revenue for fiscal year 2025 is just over $57 billion.

Meta, meanwhile, is set to spend over $70 billion this year, which makes up nearly half of its revenue.

The bottom line: 2026 may be the year investors seek a return to fundamentals that historically define prices on Wall Street: Revenue. Debt. Earnings. You know, the boring stuff.

A return to boring may be healthy for the market, but it would take the air out of Nvidia's stock, whose rise has made it the most valuable company in the world.

Yes, but: Any selloff tied to AI helps quell the bubble concerns.

"I'm hesitant to call it a bubble in any way because every time a name has even disappointed slightly the reaction has been some sort of correction which is very healthy," Singh adds.

name: S&P Global
title: AI Context Engineering; Germany's RED III Delays; and PE/VC Deal Values for November
description:
246: Context Engineering Context engineering is emerging as a crucial aspect of AI, driven by the shift to agentic work, where AI agents perform tasks independently with deterministic guidance.
It is a broader approach than prompt engineering, focusing on setting up large language models with the necessary tools, data sources and memory to succeed.
Germany may miss target start date for implementation of EU’s Renewable Energy Directive III Germany faces significant delays in implementing the EU's Renewable Energy Directive III (RED III) by the Jan. 1, 2026, deadline.
Global private equity deal value climbs 31% YOY in November 2025 Global private equity and venture capital (PE/VC) deal value increased 31% year over year to $50.11 billion in November, despite deal count dropping to 757 from 1,040.
In the year through Nov. 30, deal value reached $828.96 billion, already exceeding the full-year 2024 total.
text:
Listen: Next in Tech | Ep. 246: Context Engineering

Context engineering is emerging as a crucial aspect of AI, driven by the shift to agentic work, where AI agents perform tasks independently with deterministic guidance. It is a broader approach than prompt engineering, focusing on setting up large language models with the necessary tools, data sources and memory to succeed. This requires creating environments where agents can collaborate and maintain context through a shared layer.

In this episode of the “Next in Tech” podcast, S&P Global Market Intelligence 451 Research analysts Jean Atelsek and Alex Johnston joined host Eric Hanselman to explore this emerging discipline and its application to AI environments.

Germany may miss target start date for implementation of EU’s Renewable Energy Directive III

Germany faces significant delays in implementing the EU's Renewable Energy Directive III (RED III) by the Jan. 1, 2026, deadline. The legislation, requiring initial discussion by the executive Bundeskabinett branch before passage through the parliamentary Bundestag and Bundesrat, has been postponed since October due to a lack of consensus among ministries. This ongoing delay has left market participants uncertain about Germany's 2026 biofuel blending mandates, leading to volatility and making firm pricing "challenging."

Delayed or retroactive implementation of the legislation is likely, with one policy consultant calling the situation a "catastrophe for the whole market." With the Bundeskabinett not discussing the bill and the Bundestag requiring multiple readings, full legal assent before year-end is almost impossible. This situation creates regulatory ambiguity, particularly regarding double-counting incentives for advanced biofuels, and raises competitiveness concerns for neighboring markets, such as the Netherlands, where timely implementation is expected.

Global private equity deal value climbs 31% YOY in November 2025

Global private equity and venture capital (PE/VC) deal value increased 31% year over year to $50.11 billion in November, despite deal count dropping to 757 from 1,040. In the year through Nov. 30, deal value reached $828.96 billion, already exceeding the full-year 2024 total. The technology, media and telecommunications sector was the most active, recording 245 private equity-backed transactions and accounting for 25% of all deals. Within this sector, application software led with 117 transactions. November featured 11 private equity-backed transactions worth at least $1 billion, with the largest being Clayton Dubilier & Rice's $10.31 billion acquisition of bubble-wrap maker Sealed Air.

name: Michelin
title: New Mexico Jury Slams Michelin with $220M Verdict in Defect Case - The Texas Lawbook
description:
A jury in New Mexico sided with a Texas family on Friday, agreeing a defect in a Michelin tire was to blame for an incident that left three people dead.
The lawsuit was filed in New Mexico district court in San Miguel County on behalf of Rosalva Marin, Laura Marin Zamarripa and Alexis Zamarippa against Michelin North America and Discount Tire Company of New Mexico in 2021.

name: Ralph Lauren
title: The 'Ralph Lauren Christmas' Trend: Aspirational Nostalgia and the Luxe Lifestyle Vibe
description:
The Strategic Role of Accessibility While the look is intrinsically linked to a luxury brand, its success is fueled by its perceived accessibility.
These activities transform a shopping trip into a shareable, immersive "Ralph Lauren Christmas" experience, fueling social media content and brand engagement.
Lifestyle as Longevity Insurance The focus on home décor, cafes, and the Olympic uniforms reinforces Ralph Lauren’s broader lifestyle credentials.
The trend's power lies in the fact that it makes the aspirational Ralph Lauren aesthetic achievable across all price points.
What is their income?Mid-to-High Disposable Income for core Ralph Lauren product, but the trend's diffusion allows for participation from lower income brackets via "get the look for less" strategies.
text:
InsightTrendsWorld

10 minutes ago

16 min read

What is the Aspirational Nostalgia Trend: The Viral Commercialization of Heritage Luxury

This trend is the social media-driven virality of the Ralph Lauren Corporation's meticulously curated, heritage-rich holiday aesthetic, which blends elements of classic American prep, cozy sophistication, and "old money" elegance into a widely sought-after lifestyle look for both fashion and home décor. The trend has sent searches for “Ralph Lauren inspired Christmas” soaring by 3,000% on Pinterest, demonstrating the consumer desire to buy into a feeling of classic, comforting tradition.

The Signature Aesthetic DNA

The aesthetic is defined by a consistent, rich visual language: plaid trimmings, pine garlands, rich red and hunter green color palettes, brass accents, dark wood, and the Polo Bear mascot. This uniformity, polished over a decade, provided the ideal visual blueprint for social media content creators to easily replicate and trend.

Fashion-Meets-Home Décor Loop

Unlike most trends, "Ralph Lauren Christmas" is a complete lifestyle package, covering both apparel (cable-knit sweaters, blazers) and home décor (tartan tablecloths, brass bells, roaring fireplaces). This cross-category resonance amplifies the brand's presence, reinforcing its desire to be seen as a broader luxury lifestyle entity, as highlighted by its home décor and hospitality offerings (cafes and restaurants).

The Strategic Role of Accessibility

While the look is intrinsically linked to a luxury brand, its success is fueled by its perceived accessibility. Consumers can buy the core Ralph Lauren staples or achieve the "inspired" look for less at chains like Vans or Amazon, a dynamic that ensures broad, fast adoption across various price points, giving Ralph Lauren the halo effect of the trend without sacrificing its luxury positioning.

Consumer Insights: The trend is an emotional investment in tradition; consumers are purchasing a feeling of comfort, stability, and curated luxury, often using core brand items (like the Polo Bear sweater) to anchor their self-styled look.Insights for Brands: A fully realized lifestyle aesthetic that spans clothing, home, and hospitality is marketing gold; invest in building a consistent, emotionally resonant visual world that consumers can easily reference and replicate.

Why it is the topic trending: The Convergence of Timeliness, Trend, and Tradition

This trend is a case study in perfect timing, sitting squarely at the intersection of several powerful, reinforcing cultural trends that naturally amplify Ralph Lauren’s long-term brand strategy.

The Return to Sophisticated Dressing (Preppy and Quarter Zip Crazes)

The current fashion cycle favors preppy style (cable-knit sweaters, blazers) and sophisticated casual dressing (the quarter zip), categories where Ralph Lauren is the undisputed, authentic category leader. This natural trend alignment made the brand’s core product range highly desirable before the holiday season even began.

The Comfort of Tradition in Uncertain Times

The trend's emphasis on pine garlands, cozy fires, and traditional colors taps directly into a deeply rooted consumer desire for nostalgia, comfort, and safety during the holidays, especially in uncertain times. This emotional anchor makes the aesthetic more compelling than fleeting, purely novelty-driven trends.

The Final Wave of "Quiet Luxury"

The aesthetic successfully marries the "old money" vibe of quiet luxury (polished image, heritage staples, upscale retail strategy) with holiday maximalism. This allows consumers to participate in the perceived exclusivity of quiet luxury while satisfying the seasonal desire for abundance and expression, creating a compelling, aspirational style.

Consumer Insights: Your desire for comfort and stability is influencing your spending; look for brands that offer authentic heritage and classic styles that feel like a reliable long-term investment.Insights for Brands: Success comes from strategic timing and brand authenticity; ensure your brand is the undisputed, genuine leader in the core aesthetic that happens to align with the dominant cultural mood (e.g., nostalgia, prep).

Detailed findings: Strategic Elevation and Experiential Marketing

The findings show that the organic viral trend was accelerated by Ralph Lauren’s deliberate, years-long strategy to elevate its image and invest in experiential and culturally sensitive marketing.

Luxury House Elevation Strategy

Under CEO Patrice Louvet, Ralph Lauren has strategically elevated its image, moving closer to European luxury houses like LVMH by cutting back on less "chichi" retailers and upgrading its outlet stores and core retail locations. This repositioning made the brand feel luxe and aspirational just as the "old money" aesthetic began trending.

Experiential Retail and Brand Immersiveness

The company augmented the trend with experiential holiday pop-ups in global cities (Seoul, London, Tokyo) offering activities like hot chocolate sipping, seasonal floral displays, and visits to Santa's grotto. These activities transform a shopping trip into a shareable, immersive "Ralph Lauren Christmas" experience, fueling social media content and brand engagement.

Culturally Sensitive Storytelling

Ralph Lauren cleverly leverages its "American Dream" narrative while simultaneously embracing the country’s diversity. The 2022 collaboration with historically Black colleges and the collection celebrating Oak Bluffs demonstrate a strategy of inclusive storytelling that broadens the brand's appeal and deepens its relevance to a wider, modern consumer base.

Consumer Insights: Look for brands that offer experiences and cultural depth, not just products; the ability to pose for a selfie by a themed installation (like the vintage red pick-up truck) is part of the purchase value.Insights for Brands: Experiential marketing (pop-ups, cafes) is vital for converting viral buzz into real-world engagement; use these touchpoints to create highly Instagrammable moments that solidify the brand's aspirational lifestyle credentials.

Key success factors of Ralph Lauren Christmas Trend: Authentic Vision and Platform Leverage

The trend's success is rooted in the founder's enduring, authentic vision, the strategic elevation of the brand's status, and the masterful use of the social media landscape.

The Power of an Authentic, Enduring Vision

The founder's ability to sell a consistent, aspirational vision of the American dream, despite his own background, is the core emotional anchor of the brand. This timeless, authentic vision gave the aesthetic the stability to be rediscovered and celebrated by a new, nostalgic generation.

Strategic Brand Elevation

Ralph Lauren ensured it was ready for the moment by focusing on its core products (cable-knit sweaters, blazers) and aggressively improving its distribution quality and store presentation. This prepared the brand to capitalize on the organic trend, ensuring consumers met an elevated, "luxe" version of the brand.

Organic Amplification and Social Media Genius

While the trend grew organically, the brand successfully augmented the association through marketing efforts like the holiday pop-ups. Generating about $6 million in social media value from these efforts proves the genius of creating real-world, highly visual moments that naturally generate user-generated content (e.g., selfies with the red pick-up truck).

Consumer Insights: Invest in brands with a clear, timeless vision; their enduring quality is what makes them popular in the viral nostalgia cycles of social media.Insights for Brands: The most successful viral trends are often organic but augmented; create visually rich, real-world experiences that are tailor-made for user-generated content and social sharing.

Key Takeaway: Lifestyle Branding is the Ultimate Hedge Against Trend Cycles

The primary takeaway is that by successfully establishing an all-encompassing lifestyle brand that extends far beyond apparel (into home décor, hospitality, and cultural narrative), Ralph Lauren has built a powerful hedge against the fickle nature of fashion trend cycles, allowing it to remain relevant even as specific styles like "preppy" or "quiet luxury" peak and wane.

Lifestyle as Longevity Insurance

The focus on home décor, cafes, and the Olympic uniforms reinforces Ralph Lauren’s broader lifestyle credentials. When the preppy clothing look wanes, the brand can pivot to its other distinct sub-brands (Purple Label, Double RL) or categories (handbags, hospitality) to maintain sales momentum.

Halo Effect on the Core Business

The "Ralph Lauren Christmas" buzz is translating into tangible results, with sales through its own US stores and website tracking ahead of consensus expectations. This confirms that cultural relevance directly drives golden quarter revenue, providing a significant halo effect across the entire business.

The Power of Brand Diversity

The brand's decision to retain distinct sub-brands gives it the structural flexibility to adapt to whatever the next aesthetic fancy may be. This diversified portfolio minimizes risk compared to single-category luxury players.

Consumer Insights: A brand's resilience and longevity are a sign of value; purchasing a core piece from a brand with diverse lifestyle offerings is a safer investment against rapidly changing trends.Insights for Brands: The goal is to evolve from a fashion house to a cultural institution; use your core aesthetic to build an immersive lifestyle narrative that extends into high-margin categories like home and hospitality.

Market and Cultural Signals Supporting the Trend: The Post-Luxury Nostalgia Boom

The "Ralph Lauren Christmas" trend is directly supported by market and cultural signals that indicate a widespread consumer yearning for comfort, nostalgia, and a softened, traditional form of luxury following years of digital-first chaos and economic uncertainty.

The Nostalgia Cycle and Comfort Consumption

The appeal is directly linked to the emotional comfort of nostalgia, channeling the festive spirit of "It's a Wonderful Life" and the "Home Alone" aesthetic. This signals a cultural move towards comfort consumption where purchases are justified by the positive emotional memories or feelings they evoke.

The Broadening of Americana and Heritage

The collaboration with Historically Black Colleges and the Oak Bluffs collection demonstrate that the market supports a more inclusive, contemporary definition of Americana and heritage. This allows the brand to tap into a wider demographic of next-generation consumers who prioritize cultural diversity and authentic storytelling.

The Democratization of Aspiration

The fact that competitors like Vans and Hugo Boss are adopting the red-and-green plaid, tartan, and teddy bear motifs confirms the aesthetic's status as a mass-market commercial theme. The trend's power lies in the fact that it makes the aspirational Ralph Lauren aesthetic achievable across all price points.

Consumer Insights: Your desire for tradition is a powerful economic driver; recognize that even budget-friendly retailers are now catering to this demand for classic, comforting aesthetics.Insights for Brands: The market rewards brands that can redefine and broaden their heritage narrative to be inclusive and culturally sensitive, ensuring the "dream" they sell resonates with a diverse, modern audience.

Description of consumers: The Culturally Literate Comfort Seeker

The key consumer segment driving this trend is the Culturally Literate Comfort Seeker: a digitally engaged shopper who values brand heritage, seeks emotional stability through traditional aesthetics, and uses high-quality, recognizable items to signify refined taste and cultural understanding.

Aspirational but Discerning: They are drawn to the "old money vibe" but are savvy about pricing and appreciate that Ralph Lauren is looking both "luxe and accessible" compared to aggressively priced European rivals.

Emotionally Driven: They are motivated by the desire for the comfort, tradition, and stability that the aesthetic provides during the holidays, viewing the brand's products as a form of emotional security.

Socially Engaged Content Generator: They are active on platforms like Pinterest (where searches surged 3,000%) and social media, queuing for selfies at the pop-ups and generating the content that fuels the trend's virality.

Consumer Insights: Your emotional needs for comfort and tradition are key purchasing drivers; choose brands whose aesthetics authentically align with that feeling.Insights for Brands: The target consumer is looking for heritage with a contemporary conscience; continue to invest in inclusive storytelling that broadens the definition of the brand's American dream.

Consumer Detailed Summary: The Modern Heirloom Builder

Who are them:Modern Heirloom Builders—consumers prioritizing timeless pieces and emotional value, often leveraging social media to curate and share their refined lifestyle.

What is their age?: Primarily Millennials and Gen Z (the next-generation consumers), who are driving the TikTok/Pinterest virality, coupled with core, loyal Gen X and Baby Boomer consumers who drive high-value purchases.

What is their gender?Broad Appeal, spanning traditional menswear staples (blazers, rugby shirts) to the growing womenswear focus (handbags) and gender-neutral home décor.

What is their income?Mid-to-High Disposable Income for core Ralph Lauren product, but the trend's diffusion allows for participation from lower income brackets via "get the look for less" strategies.

What is their lifestyle:Established, Culturally Active, and Family-Oriented, seeking to host and curate classic, traditional holiday experiences in their urban or suburban homes.

What type of shopper is (based on motivation):Aspirational Shopper with an Emotional Value Focus, motivated by quality, longevity, and the powerful feeling of heritage and tradition.

What is consumer motivation: Investing in Timeless Emotional Security

Emotional Counter-Trend to Volatility: In uncertain times, consumers gravitate towards the stability and predictability of classic, heritage-rooted brands like Ralph Lauren, seeing the aesthetic as a safe haven from fleeting fads.

The Value of Longevity: The motivation is to purchase "forever pieces"—cable-knit sweaters, blazers, quality home goods—that transcend seasonal trends, aligning with the brand's strategy of focusing on products it is best known for.

The Desire to Be a Lifestyle Curator: Consumers are motivated to use the aesthetic to curate and communicate their own elevated lifestyle on social media, viewing the clothes and décor as tools for self-expression and social signalling.

Consumer Insights: Your desire for quality and tradition is your long-term value guide; prioritize classic staples over highly trend-driven items.Insights for Brands: Frame products not as purchases, but as heirloom-quality investments in a stable, desirable lifestyle, appealing directly to the consumer's need for security and tradition.

Strategic Trend Forecast: Global Lifestyle Expansion and LVMH-Style Event Takeovers

Global Expansion of Experiential Touchpoints: Following the pop-ups in Seoul and Tokyo, expect Ralph Lauren to aggressively roll out its hospitality and home décor concepts in key global cities to transform the brand's aesthetic into immersive, year-round destinations, solidifying its lifestyle status.

The LVMH-Style Event Takeover: The brand's outfitting of the US Olympic teams presents a massive marketing opportunity. Ralph Lauren should consider an LVMH-style takeover of a major cultural or sporting event (especially the 2028 LA Summer Games) to generate a massive, sustained global buzz and solidify its position as a top-tier luxury lifestyle conglomerate.

Strategic Handbag and Womenswear Growth: To maintain momentum when the preppy look wanes, the company will continue to aggressively invest in womenswear, particularly handbags, which offer high margins and a strong entry point into the luxury market for female consumers.

Consumer Insights: Watch for Ralph Lauren's high-profile event activations; they signal where the brand is placing its biggest strategic bets and where the next big trend will emerge.Insights for Brands: Success lies in global, cohesive lifestyle immersion; use a tiered brand structure and high-impact cultural events to maintain visibility beyond core product cycles.

Areas of innovation: Sub-Brand Agility and Connected Retail

Sub-Brand and Brand Portfolio Agility: Ralph Lauren's key innovation is its use of distinct sub-brands (Purple Label, Double RL) as a built-in adaptive mechanism. This innovation allows the company to tap into whatever fancy comes next (e.g., heritage workwear through Double RL) without jeopardizing the core Polo identity.

Advanced Connected Retail: The focus on core stores and online integration (US stores and website sales tracking well) will require innovation in "connected retail"—using digital tools and AI to personalize the high-end in-store experience, anticipate consumer needs, and create seamless transitions between the physical store and the online lifestyle world.

Marketing Value Measurement: Innovation in marketing will involve advanced use of platforms like Launchmetrics to accurately measure the social media value ($6 million generated by pop-ups) and ROI of non-traditional, experiential activations, ensuring future marketing spend is optimized for cultural impact.

Consumer Insights: Shop across the brand's sub-labels to find the aesthetic that best suits your changing personal style; the diversity of the brand is its strength.Insights for Brands: Invest in a multi-label structure that acts as a hedge; this sub-brand agility is the new core competency for long-term luxury survival.

Core Macro Trends: Luxury-to-Mass Diffusion and The Comfort Economy

The "Ralph Lauren Christmas" phenomenon is a powerful expression of the Luxury-to-Mass Diffusion trend and the broader cultural pivot toward the Comfort Economy.

Luxury-to-Mass Diffusion (Aesthetic Copying): The aesthetic's viral success and its adoption by mass-market competitors like Vans and Amazon prove the efficiency of this trend. A high-end brand sets the aesthetic, and its visual elements (plaid, teddy bear motifs) rapidly diffuse and are copied across the entire retail spectrum.

The Comfort Economy (Nostalgia and Tradition): The trend is fundamentally driven by consumer demand for comfort, tradition, and security in an unstable world. The aesthetic acts as a cultural security blanket, prioritizing emotional warmth and classic styling over sharp, conceptual fashion.

The Lifestyle Conglomerate: Ralph Lauren’s success is part of the macro trend of Fashion as Lifestyle Conglomerate, where brands must generate significant revenue from categories outside of apparel (home, hospitality) to ensure long-term stability and brand relevance.

Consumer Insights: The aesthetics you see at all price points are often dictated by a few luxury brand leaders; your choice is between the original's quality and the copy's affordability.Insights for Brands: The greatest value is in being the originator of the viral aesthetic; your cultural resonance dictates the size of the subsequent mass-market trend.

Core Consumer Trend: The Heritage-Seeking Style Investor

The core consumer trend is the Heritage-Seeking Style Investor: a shopper who views their clothing and home décor as long-term assets, prioritizing brands with a rich history, transparent quality, and an aesthetic that promises lasting relevance.

Prioritization of Quality over Quantity: They value the quality of core classics (cable-knit sweaters) that transcend trends, aligning with the principle of investing in pieces with high perceived longevity and value.

Demand for Emotional Richness: They actively seek brands that provide a rich emotional narrative (the American dream, tradition) that adds a layer of meaning to their purchases beyond mere utility.

Social Currency of "Timelessness": In the rapid-fire world of social media, the ability to post an aesthetic that reads as "timeless" or "old money" provides a higher form of social currency than posting an ephemeral fast-fashion trend.

Consumer Insights: A brand's history and core product focus are your most reliable indicators of future value; buy the classics, not the fleeting fashion items.Insights for Brands: The focus should be on communicating enduring value and heritage rather than chasing every seasonal fad, ensuring the brand maintains its status as the benchmark for "timelessness."

Core Strategy: Balancing Luxury Elevation with Inclusive Storytelling

The core strategy driving this commercial success is the precarious but potent balance between aggressive brand elevation toward the luxury segment and a deliberate, authentic commitment to inclusive cultural storytelling that broadens the brand's reach and relevance.

Strategic Retail Disruption: The move to cut back on less chichi retailers and invest in core stores signals a commitment to elevating brand perception, making the brand feel more exclusive and higher-end.

Inclusive Heritage Narrative: The collaborations with Historically Black Colleges and the Oak Bluffs collection are a crucial strategy to ensure the "American dream" narrative is seen as inclusive, diverse, and relevant to the next generation of consumers.

Product Focus and Core Reinforcement: The strategy of concentrating on products it is best known for (70% core business) provides a stable base, allowing the brand to be ready for moments like the preppy and Christmas aesthetic trends.

Consumer Insights: The most powerful brands are those that evolve their heritage to be relevant and inclusive today; support brands that reflect contemporary cultural values.Insights for Brands: The future of luxury demands a dual strategy: elevate image and control distribution while simultaneously ensuring your brand narrative is authentically diverse and culturally broad.

Core Industry Trend: The Chief Executive as Chief Curator

The core industry trend is the transformation of the CEO role into the Chief Curator—a visionary who ensures the brand maintains its creative integrity, elevates its positioning, and leverages both cultural heritage and global market opportunities, much like Patrice Louvet balancing Ralph Lauren’s vision with market logic.

Creative and Commercial Synthesis: The CEO's role is no longer just operational but involves balancing "magic and logic"—upholding the founder's creative vision while driving digital transformation and disciplined operational growth.

The Focus on Long-Term Value: The move to reduce marketing spend as a percentage of revenue and invest in core products and quality distribution demonstrates a shift away from short-term gains toward sustainable, long-term brand equity.

The Global Luxury Race: The strategic move closer to European luxury houses like LVMH signals that the American heritage brand is competing directly in the global luxury arena, emphasizing its aspirational value and timelessness.

Consumer Insights: The strategic direction of a brand's CEO is a key indicator of its future value; look for leaders who prioritize brand equity and long-term vision over quick trend-chasing.Insights for Brands: The modern CEO must be a visionary curator who embeds the brand's heritage into a disciplined, digitally-led growth strategy, prioritizing sustainable value creation.

Core Motivation: The Desire to Purchase a "Perfect" Moment

The core motivation driving the viral adoption is the Desire to Purchase a "Perfect" Moment—a yearning to own the idealized, curated, and emotionally rich holiday scene that Ralph Lauren has spent decades perfecting in its advertising, thereby transforming a commodity purchase into an emotional asset.

Escapism and Idealization: The aesthetic offers a form of escapism into a warm, perfect, and orderly world (pine garlands, roaring fires), which is a powerful psychological driver for holiday consumption.

The Image-Driven Imperative: The consumer is motivated by the desire to replicate and share this idealized image on social media (queuing for selfies, Pinterest searches), making the trend a social and cultural imperative.

The Emotional Value of Heritage: The products are seen as tangible elements of a desirable, established tradition, providing a psychological "investment" in a feeling of belonging and stability.

Consumer Insights: Your purchases are a reflection of an ideal; buy the pieces that allow you to curate and realize the "perfect" scene you aspire to share.Insights for Brands: Sell the scene, not the product; design every retail, store, and pop-up experience to be a ready-made, high-quality backdrop for the consumer's self-generated aspirational content.

Final Insight: The Halo Effect of Cultural Nostalgia

The success of "Ralph Lauren Christmas" teaches that a brand's most valuable asset is an authentic, fully developed, and culturally resonant heritage narrative that can be effortlessly rediscovered by a new generation seeking emotional comfort and stability. This halo effect of cultural nostalgia translates directly into increased traffic, sales, and enduring brand equity, proving that timelessness is the ultimate form of viral marketing.

Consumer Insights: The value of a brand is tied to the strength of the feeling it evokes; choose brands whose history feels like a positive part of your aspirational future.

Insights for Brands: Nurture your brand's heritage as an asset, but ensure you create modern, inclusive cultural collaborations to make that heritage relevant to the next generation of high-value consumers.

Final Thought (summary): Ralph Lauren's Strategic Triumph in the Comfort Economy

The "Ralph Lauren Christmas" aesthetic is a strategic triumph, demonstrating the powerful commercial returns generated when a luxury brand's disciplined, decade-long elevation strategy perfectly intersects with a dominant consumer trend for comfort, nostalgia, and quiet luxury. The core consumer is the Heritage-Seeking Style Investor, a digitally savvy shopper who uses the brand's aesthetic—defined by tartan, deep greens and reds, and Polo Bear motifs—to purchase a feeling of timeless, aspirational stability during uncertain times. The future implication for the industry is the necessity of becoming a cohesive lifestyle conglomerate, moving beyond apparel and using high-impact, experiential marketing (like the global pop-ups) to transform a well-honed aesthetic into a viral cultural moment, thereby securing enduring sales growth and insulating the brand against inevitable fashion trend cycles.

Trends 2025: Comfort Nostalgia: The Psychology of Softness and Sentiment

This macro trend describes the widespread consumer behavior, particularly across Millennials and Gen Z, of actively seeking comfort, stability, and emotional well-being by engaging with and purchasing products that evoke fond memories and a sense of familiarity from past decades. In fashion, this translates to styles that prioritize relaxed silhouettes, familiar heritage codes, and a sense of timeless quality over fleeting, challenging trends.

The Emotional Security Purchase The trend is a direct psychological response to global uncertainty, rapid technological change (AI, metaverse), and the fast-paced digital world, which leaves many feeling disconnected. Nostalgic cues—whether from the Y2K era or a heritage brand like Ralph Lauren—activate emotional memories linked to comfort, security, and simpler times, leading to higher customer trust and loyalty. Consumers are willing to pay a premium for items that provide this emotional relief, often referred to as "comfort buying."

The Rise of the 'Kidult' Consumer A significant driver is the rise of the "Kidult"—adults seeking products that trigger nostalgia and recreate the comfort of childhood. For fashion, this translates into an acceptance of playful elements and whimsy (e.g., the Polo Bear, teddy bear motifs, Y2K accessories like butterfly clips) but presented with an elevated, self-aware twist that meets adult expectations of quality and style.

The Blended, Unburdened Aesthetic The comfort is manifested in design through flowing, relaxed silhouettes (wide-leg denim, elevated athleisure, oversized cardigans) and tactile materials (luxe cashmere, soft faux fur, sherpa linings) that feel huggable and non-restrictive. The nostalgia is often a "composite" aesthetic, freely mixing references from different decades (e.g., '90s plaid with Y2K silhouettes) to evoke a general feeling of familiarity rather than historical accuracy.

Implication for Fashion Industry: Brands must pivot their design and marketing from selling seasonal novelty to selling emotional resonance and enduring value. This requires investing in storytelling, material quality, and design longevity to create products that function as tangible links to positive memories and provide psychological comfort in an unstable world.

name: Michelin
title: Jury Returns $220 Million Verdict Against Michelin in Deadly Crash - Yahoo Finance
description:
The failure caused the car being driven by Laura Zamarippa to veer into oncoming traffic, causing a head-on collision with another vehicle.
The faulty tire was purchased at a store operated by Discount Tire Company of New Mexico, also a defendant in the case.
The jury placed 100% of the liability for the tire failure on Michelin.
"Michelin fought hard — all the way to the New Mexico Supreme Court — in an effort to not produce certain emails and documents that had not been produced before," said attorney Wes Ball of Kaster Lynch Farrar & Ball in Houston.
About Kaster Lynch Farrar & Ball The trial lawyers at Kaster Lynch Farrar & Ball have hard-earned expertise in cases against global auto and tire manufacturers over various automotive defects, as well as tire-tread separation defects that can cause vehicles to lose control and roll over, often at highway speeds and without warning.
text:
Faulty tire design, manufacturing led to death of three generations of New Mexico family

LAS VEGAS, N.M, December 12, 2025--(BUSINESS WIRE)--A New Mexico jury has returned a $220 million verdict, finding that the Michelin North America tire company was liable for a deadly crash that killed three members of a Texas family in the summer of 2021.

Laura Zamarippa, Rosalva Marin and 14-year-old Alexis Zamarippa died when a Michelin-produced LTX M tire installed on the front driver’s side violently separated while the three family members were driving on a rural highway in Gaines County, Texas.

The failure caused the car being driven by Laura Zamarippa to veer into oncoming traffic, causing a head-on collision with another vehicle. As a result of the crash, Ms. Zamarippa and Ms. Marin were pronounced dead at the scene, while Alexis died shortly after being transported to a medical facility by air ambulance.

The faulty tire was purchased at a store operated by Discount Tire Company of New Mexico, also a defendant in the case. The jury placed 100% of the liability for the tire failure on Michelin.

"Michelin fought hard — all the way to the New Mexico Supreme Court — in an effort to not produce certain emails and documents that had not been produced before," said attorney Wes Ball of Kaster Lynch Farrar & Ball in Houston. "The court denied that request, and we believe those materials introduced at trial were key in showing Michelin’s decision to gamble with people’s lives."

The case is Grano et al. v. Michelin North America, Inc. et al., No. D-412-CV-2021-00197 in the Fourth Judicial District Court for San Miguel County, New Mexico.

About Kaster Lynch Farrar & Ball

The trial lawyers at Kaster Lynch Farrar & Ball have hard-earned expertise in cases against global auto and tire manufacturers over various automotive defects, as well as tire-tread separation defects that can cause vehicles to lose control and roll over, often at highway speeds and without warning. The firm has secured verdicts and settlements against some of the largest automakers in the world in cases involving auto defects. For more information, visit klfblaw.com.

name: Ralph Lauren
title: Jennifer Lawrence and Steak Au Poivre? Raoul's 50th Anniversary Party Had Both | Vogue
authors: Gaby Keiderling, Paul Chi, Kristen Bateman, Freya Drohan, Zachary Weiss, Savannah Hanoum, Kelsey Stewart, Aaron Royce, Hamish Bowles, Kiana Murden
description:
In honor of its half-century milestone, beloved SoHo mainstay Raoul’s teamed up with Moda Operandi and Chloë Sevigny to celebrate in true French American fashion.
A quintessential intimate date night, Raoul’s style, commenced.
Tables of two and booths of four were occupied, with custom Moda Domus ceramic ash trays and Warby Parker reading glasses nestled alongside the place settings.
By 8.30 p.m., a surprise burlesque performance dazzled the room, with Jennifer Lawrence watching on with delight.
A gigantic tiramisu sheet cake—so massive that it took three people to light the cake—was served on custom Moda Domus x Raoul’s dessert plates.
text:
Amidst an abundance of Manhattan restaurants, on Tuesday night it was evident just how much one institution has made its mark. In honor of its half-century milestone, beloved SoHo mainstay Raoul’s teamed up with Moda Operandi and Chloë Sevigny to celebrate in true French American fashion. In other words, a steak and martini-filled dinner followed by a bash in the bistro.

Under the instantly-recognizable tin ceiling, a lucky posse of invitees mingled by the bar, picking up Grey Goose cocktails and glasses of bubbly to take to their seats. A quintessential intimate date night, Raoul’s style, commenced. Tables of two and booths of four were occupied, with custom Moda Domus ceramic ash trays and Warby Parker reading glasses nestled alongside the place settings. Finely-dressed waiters appeared with oysters bienville gratinées, a warm goats cheese salad, and artichoke vinaigrette to start. And after that, there was only one acceptable phrase heard: Steak au-poivre, s’il vous plait.

While the food was prepared, the room was abuzz. By 8.30 p.m., a surprise burlesque performance dazzled the room, with Jennifer Lawrence watching on with delight. Fashion designers Jackson Wiederhoeft and Christopher John Rodgers had gotten their hands on crayons—transforming the paper tablecloths into chef-d'œuvres—while Lauren Santo Domingo chatted with Brandon Maxwell and Stephanie Suberville of Heirlome.

The appetizers appeared and were cleared just as fast, plates of steaks were reduced to mere peppercorns as cornets upon cornets of frites flowed from the kitchen. A gigantic tiramisu sheet cake—so massive that it took three people to light the cake—was served on custom Moda Domus x Raoul’s dessert plates. Owners Guy and Karim Raoul gave a heartfelt toast to the crowd: “Here's to 50 more years,” they said, followed by a host of hoots and cheers.

A late-night party ensued, swelling bigger and bigger with each passing hour. An influx of notables were scattered around the bar, admiring, and wearing, the merchandise collaboration—graphic 8th Story baseball caps and Les Tien hoodies and baby tees—while they waited for the diners to finish their slices of birthday cake to come join them.

The later it got, nobody wanted to leave, as more and more people arrive to pack in tightly against the paintings and nude drawing-covered walls. Hours later, guests walked out of the undiscerning door onto the streets of Soho, bellies full and hearts even fuller.
