name: HP Inc
title: KTM RC450 Leaks: KTM's Coming for Kawasaki's Lunch Money - RideApart.com
description:
KTM's upcoming RC450 specs have been leaked due to Chinese type-approval documents filed by the joint-venture operation that is KTM and CFMoto.
Powering the little orange rocket is the same 270-degree 449cc parallel twin engine that debuted in the CFMoto 450SR.
One place the RC450 differs from the 450 SR-S is its 1,360mm wheelbase, which is 10mm shorter than the CFMoto's.
You don't have to look too long to recognize that the RC450 has two decently sized winglets at the front.
Now that KTM is coming out with what'll likely be the most powerful motorcycle in this category, is it going to take everyone else's lunch money?
text:
KTM's upcoming RC450 specs have been leaked due to Chinese type-approval documents filed by the joint-venture operation that is KTM and CFMoto. Thank god for homologation documents. The long-awaited update to the Austrian brand's entry-level sportsbike is heavily based on the CFMoto 450SR-S, except it's, well, better or at least sportier.

Powering the little orange rocket is the same 270-degree 449cc parallel twin engine that debuted in the CFMoto 450SR. But, unlike the 50 HP that this unit puts out in the 450 SR-S, it'll produce an extra 5 HP in the RC450, bringing the grand total to 55 HP and, interestingly, making it non-A2 compliant in Europe without restricting the power. Either way, it's going to beat the US version of the niche-topping Ninja 500, which produces 51 HP.

Cradling the parallel twin is a trellis-style frame that also features on CFMoto's 450 SR-S, but whereas the 450 SR-S tips the scales with a dry weight of 171kg, KTM has ensured that RC450 has been made on a calorie restriction and weighs just 168kg dry. The bottom line is that the KTM has more power and less weight than the CFMoto that donated so much of its DNA to put this bike into production so quickly.

Stay informed with our newsletter every weekday

For more info, read our Privacy Policy & Terms of Use.

One place the RC450 differs from the 450 SR-S is its 1,360mm wheelbase, which is 10mm shorter than the CFMoto's. So the KTM should give it a racier riding position. The type approval document also revealed that the RC450 will be fitted with Bosch 10.3MB ABS, but we don't know what other rider aids await us.

The RC450 steps up the sportiness in other areas, too, with its WP suspension, WP steering damper, and clip-ons that appear to be mounted below the top yoke in a racier position than the 450 SR-S. Again, exaggerating the fact that this is made to attack tracks are revised pegs and foot controls that are mounted quite high on the RC450, and a quickshifter load sensor. Then there's its style, or rather lack of.

You don't have to look too long to recognize that the RC450 has two decently sized winglets at the front. For a bike that tops out at around 120 mph, on a good day, I can't imagine how often the downforce from these winglets will come into play and whether they're worth the trade-off in style points. Speaking of style, I'll leave it up to you to decide whether you like the front blinkers and mirrors, which have been taken directly off the 450 SR.

The RC390 was hugely competitive in this market thanks to a racy chassis, but couldn't keep up as other manufacturers developed more powerful engines before the Kawasaki Ninja 500 essentially became the de facto motorcycle in this niche—Aprilia's RS 457 is raising eyebrows, however. Now that KTM is coming out with what'll likely be the most powerful motorcycle in this category, is it going to take everyone else's lunch money?

name: Delta Airlines
title: Delta adding additonal flights for upcoming college football playoffs - ABC 6
description:
Delta has fans covered for the college football playoff quarterfinals, adding flights to help ease travel towards the end of the year.
"Bowl season is all about tradition, rivalries and unforgettable moments as teams battle it out for a place in the championship,” Amy Martin said, Vice President of Network Planning.
“By adding additional flights and building off Delta’s well-positioned existing network, we are making sure college football fans can be there to cheer on their team when and where it matters the most.” Flights from CMH (John Glenn International Airport) to DFW (Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport) have been added, including flights from ATL-MIA, IND-LAX, and ATL-MSY.
The press release states that flights will go fast, so view the available options and full flight schedule here.
Delta also boasts live satellite TV, so fans can stream and enjoy the game from the air.
text:

name: Ecolab
title: Industrial Water Treatment Market | Global Market Analysis Report - 2035
description:
Industrial Water Treatment Market Forecast and Outlook 2025 to 2035 The global industrial water treatment market is projected to reach USD 80.5 billion by 2035, recording an absolute increase of USD 32.5 billion over the forecast period.
Industrial Water Treatment Market Year-over-Year Forecast 2025 to 2035 Between 2025 and 2029, the industrial water treatment market is projected to expand from USD 48.0 billion to USD 59.1 billion, resulting in a value increase of USD 11.1 billion, which represents 34.2% of the total forecast growth for the period.
Industrial Water Treatment Market Key Takeaways Metric Value Market Value (2025) USD 48.0 billion Market Forecast Value (2035) USD 80.5 billion Forecast CAGR (2025-2035) 5.3% Why is the Industrial Water Treatment Market Growing?
The chemical treatment segment represents the dominant force in the industrial water treatment market, capturing 27.5% of the total market share in 2025.
Competitive Landscape of the Industrial Water Treatment Market The industrial water treatment market features approximately 20-30 meaningful players with moderate concentration, where the top three companies control roughly 25-30% of global market share through established technology portfolios, comprehensive service capabilities, and multi-region operational presence.
text:
Industrial Water Treatment Market Forecast and Outlook 2025 to 2035

The global industrial water treatment market is projected to reach USD 80.5 billion by 2035, recording an absolute increase of USD 32.5 billion over the forecast period. The market is valued at USD 48.0 billion in 2025 and is set to rise at a CAGR of 5.3% during the assessment period.

The scope for industrial water treatment is expected to grow by approximately 1.7 times during the same period, supported by increasing regulatory pressure for wastewater compliance and sustainable water management worldwide, driving demand for advanced treatment technologies and increasing investments in water recycling systems with circular economy principles across manufacturing facilities and industrial processing operations globally.

Industrial operators and facility managers face mounting pressure to reduce water consumption and meet stringent discharge standards while addressing operational efficiency requirements and environmental sustainability commitments, with modern industrial water treatment solutions providing documented operational benefits including enhanced process water quality, reduced freshwater intake, and regulatory compliance assurance compared to conventional treatment approaches alone.

Rising water scarcity concerns and expanding zero liquid discharge mandates enabling resource conservation create substantial opportunities for technology providers and engineering firms. However, high capital investment requirements and complex system integration challenges may pose obstacles to widespread advanced treatment adoption across small and medium industrial enterprises.

The chemical treatment segment dominates market activity, driven by extensive application versatility supporting scale inhibition, corrosion control, and biological growth prevention across diverse industrial processes worldwide. Industrial facilities increasingly recognize the operational reliability of chemical treatment programs, with typical product offerings providing effective water conditioning and system protection at predictable operational costs through established chemical supply networks.

The physical treatment segment demonstrates robust presence, supported by proven filtration and separation technologies integrating mechanical purification in modern industrial water management approaches. Chemical industry applications emerge as the dominant end-use segment, reflecting critical water quality requirements and high treatment volumes in chemical manufacturing operations. Membrane technologies show strong growth potential, driven by advanced separation capabilities and zero liquid discharge system integration.

Regional dynamics show Asia Pacific maintaining market leadership, supported by rapid industrialization rates and stringent environmental regulations across manufacturing sectors. North America demonstrates steady growth trajectory driven by aging water infrastructure upgrades and increasing water reuse mandates adopting circular water management practices, while Europe emphasizes sustainability regulations and industrial decarbonization initiatives for comprehensive environmental stewardship. India leads country-level growth through rapid industrialization and major water stress conditions, followed by China supported by strong industrial expansion and strict effluent norms implementation.

The competitive landscape features moderate concentration with Veolia maintaining market leadership position at 9.5% share, while specialized players including Ecolab, Xylem, Kurita Water Industries, and Suez compete through integrated water management solutions and comprehensive technical service capabilities across diverse industrial applications.

Industrial Water Treatment Market Year-over-Year Forecast 2025 to 2035

Between 2025 and 2029, the industrial water treatment market is projected to expand from USD 48.0 billion to USD 59.1 billion, resulting in a value increase of USD 11.1 billion, which represents 34.2% of the total forecast growth for the period.

This phase of development will be shaped by rising demand for water recycling systems addressing freshwater scarcity concerns, product innovation in smart monitoring technologies with real-time water quality analytics and predictive maintenance capabilities, as well as expanding integration with industrial digitalization platforms and Internet of Things sensor networks.

Companies are establishing competitive positions through investment in membrane technology advancement, chemical formulation optimization, and strategic market expansion across engineering procurement construction contracts, build-operate-transfer models, and long-term service agreements.

From 2029 to 2035, the market is forecast to grow from USD 59.1 billion to USD 80.5 billion, adding another USD 21.4 billion, which constitutes 65.8% of the overall expansion. This period is characterized by the expansion of specialized treatment applications, including zero liquid discharge systems for water-intensive industries and advanced oxidation processes tailored for complex industrial effluents, strategic collaborations between technology providers and industrial end-users, and an enhanced focus on decentralized treatment solutions and modular system designs.

The growing emphasis on circular economy principles and rising industrial preference for integrated water-energy nexus optimization addressing operational sustainability, carbon footprint reduction, and resource recovery will drive demand for comprehensive water treatment solutions across diverse manufacturing and processing sectors.

Industrial Water Treatment Market Key Takeaways

Metric Value Market Value (2025) USD 48.0 billion Market Forecast Value (2035) USD 80.5 billion Forecast CAGR (2025-2035) 5.3%

Why is the Industrial Water Treatment Market Growing?

The industrial water treatment market grows by enabling manufacturing facilities and processing plants to achieve regulatory compliance and operational efficiency while addressing water scarcity and environmental sustainability requirements without exclusive reliance on freshwater sources and basic treatment methods. Industrial operators strive to minimize water consumption and meet increasingly stringent discharge limits while managing process reliability, equipment protection, and total cost of ownership considerations.

Contemporary industrial water treatment systems typically provide comprehensive solutions including advanced filtration achieving 99% contaminant removal, chemical conditioning programs preventing scale formation and corrosion damage. Industrial water treatment systems today enhance recycling capabilities, enabling 50-90% freshwater reduction compared to once-through water usage alone, making integrated water management essential for sustainable industrial operations.

The manufacturing industry's need for reliable water quality supporting production processes and environmental compliance creates demand for specialized treatment solutions that can provide consistent water specifications, enhance operational uptime, and support zero liquid discharge objectives without compromising product quality or facility performance.

Environmental regulatory enforcement and water scarcity pressures supporting treatment investment drive adoption in chemical manufacturing, power generation, and heavy industry applications, where water quality has direct impact on process efficiency and regulatory standing.

The accelerating global water stress affecting approximately 2 billion people in water-scarce regions creates expanding requirements for industrial water conservation and reuse technologies. Rising corporate sustainability commitments and environmental social governance reporting enable informed investment decisions and adherence to water stewardship protocols.

High initial capital expenditure and technical complexity may limit adoption rates and optimal implementation across resource-constrained facilities serving different industrial segments with varying water quality requirements and treatment sophistication levels.

Segmental Analysis

The market is segmented by technology, industry, and region. By technology, the market is divided into physical treatment, chemical treatment, biological treatment, membrane technologies, advanced oxidation processes, and sludge treatment.

Based on industry, the market is categorized into chemical industry, food & beverage, pharmaceuticals, automotive, electronics, and others. Regionally, the market is divided into Asia Pacific, Europe, North America, Latin America, and Middle East & Africa.

By Technology, Which Segment Accounts for the Dominant Market Share?

The chemical treatment segment represents the dominant force in the industrial water treatment market, capturing 27.5% of the total market share in 2025. This established technology category encompasses solutions featuring comprehensive water conditioning capabilities and operational flexibility, including corrosion inhibitors, scale preventers, biocides, and coagulants that enable effective water system protection and treatment performance across boiler systems, cooling towers, and wastewater treatment processes worldwide.

The chemical treatment segment's market leadership stems from its proven reliability and cost-effectiveness, with solutions capable of addressing diverse water quality challenges including hardness removal, pH adjustment, microbiological control, and suspended solids reduction while maintaining operational simplicity and compatibility with existing industrial infrastructure across various temperature conditions and water chemistry parameters.

Physical treatment maintains a substantial market share in the 21-23% range, serving industrial facilities that require mechanical separation and filtration technologies addressing particulate removal and clarification including sedimentation, filtration, flotation, and screening processes for primary treatment applications.

Physical treatment solutions offer fundamental treatment functionality for industrial operators enabling solid-liquid separation while providing sufficient reliability to support downstream treatment processes. The physical treatment segment demonstrates steady market presence, driven by established engineering principles and essential role in multi-stage treatment system configurations.

Within the technology category, membrane technologies demonstrate rapid growth driven by advanced separation capabilities for ultrafiltration, reverse osmosis, and nanofiltration applications supporting high-purity water production and zero liquid discharge systems, while biological treatment serves organic contaminant degradation through activated sludge and biofilm reactor processes.

Key operational advantages driving the chemical treatment segment include:

Advanced multi-functionality mechanisms with demonstrated effectiveness across scale control, corrosion prevention, biological growth inhibition, and coagulation enhancement across industrial water systems

Established dosing flexibility allowing precise chemical addition and real-time adjustment without extensive capital investment complexity for treatment optimization

Enhanced operational simplicity features enabling rapid implementation and straightforward maintenance protocols while maintaining treatment effectiveness and system reliability

Superior cost-effectiveness profile providing optimal treatment performance relative to capital expenditure and operational complexity across various industrial facility scales and water quality challenges

By Industry, Which Segment Accounts for the Largest Market Share?

Chemical industry applications dominate the industrial water treatment landscape with a 28.0% market share in 2025, reflecting the critical role of water quality management in supporting chemical manufacturing processes, cooling operations, and wastewater treatment across petrochemical refineries, specialty chemical production, and basic chemical manufacturing facilities worldwide.

The chemical industry segment's market leadership is reinforced by high water consumption intensity averaging 50-200 cubic meters per ton of product output, stringent process water specifications requiring ultra-pure water for reactions and product formulation, and complex effluent characteristics that characterize chemical production requiring sophisticated treatment approaches.

Within this segment, petrochemical refineries represent substantial water treatment demand, driven by cooling water requirements, desalination needs, and complex wastewater streams containing hydrocarbons and dissolved organics. This sub-segment benefits from established capital investment capacity and regulatory compliance pressures.

Food & beverage represents an important industry category at 20.5% share, demonstrating steady expansion through food safety requirements, product quality assurance needs, and sustainability commitments where water treatment supports ingredient processing, equipment cleaning, and effluent management in dairy processing, beverage production, and food manufacturing facilities. This segment benefits from stringent hygiene standards and consumer brand protection priorities.

Key market dynamics supporting industry growth include:

Chemical manufacturing expansion driven by global chemical production growth and increasing environmental compliance requirements, requiring comprehensive water treatment infrastructure

Food & beverage quality assurance trends require validated water treatment systems and documentation supporting food safety certifications

Integration of pharmaceutical-grade water systems enabling Good Manufacturing Practice compliance and product quality assurance

Growing emphasis on electronics manufacturing supporting semiconductor industry growth and advanced display technology requiring ultrapure water specifications

What are the Drivers, Restraints, and Key Trends of the Industrial Water Treatment Market?

The market is driven by three concrete demand factors tied to industrial sustainability. First, strengthening environmental regulations and discharge standards create expanding compliance requirements for industrial facilities, with advanced treatment technologies representing essential investments for permit maintenance in comprehensive wastewater management strategies, requiring widespread system implementation.

Second, increasing water scarcity and rising water costs drive industrial water conservation initiatives and reuse adoption, with water recycling systems demonstrating substantial operational savings through reduced freshwater intake, lower discharge volumes, and minimized utility expenses by 2030. Third, growing corporate sustainability commitments and environmental social governance priorities enable water stewardship investments that improve stakeholder relations while meeting investor expectations for environmental performance transparency.

Market restraints include high capital investment requirements and long payback periods that can challenge project approval and budget allocation across industrial facilities, particularly when advanced treatment systems require USD 1-50 million investments depending on capacity and technology complexity with 3-7 year return on investment timelines.

Complex system integration and operational expertise requirements pose another significant obstacle, as industrial water treatment implementation demands specialized engineering, careful process integration, and skilled operations personnel, potentially affecting deployment feasibility and performance optimization. Energy consumption intensity and carbon footprint concerns create additional sustainability considerations, demanding energy-efficient technologies and renewable energy integration initiatives.

Key trends indicate accelerated digital transformation and smart water management in developed markets, particularly North America and Europe, where industrial facilities demonstrate commitment to Industry 4.0 technologies enabling artificial intelligence-driven optimization, predictive maintenance analytics, and remote monitoring systems.

Zero liquid discharge system adoption trends toward complete water recycling with brine crystallization and salt recovery combine water conservation with resource recovery that optimizes environmental performance and operational sustainability. However, the market thesis could face disruption if significant breakthroughs in low-energy desalination or innovative biological treatment approaches dramatically reduce treatment costs challenging conventional technology economics.

Analysis of the Industrial Water Treatment Market by Key Countries

Country CAGR (2025-2035) India 7.3% China 6.7% Brazil 5.6% Germany 4.6% USA 4.4% UK 4.2% Japan 3.9%

The global industrial water treatment market is expanding steadily, with India leading at a 7.3% CAGR through 2035, driven by rapid industrialization acceleration, major water stress conditions, and strengthening environmental enforcement. China follows at 6.7%, supported by strong industrial expansion, strict effluent norms implementation, and comprehensive environmental protection campaigns. Brazil records 5.6%, reflecting industrial growth momentum, increasing regulatory compliance requirements, and water resource management priorities.

Germany advances at 4.6%, leveraging strong circular economy policies, industrial sustainability leadership, and advanced technology adoption. USA posts 4.4%, focusing on high regulatory standards, stable industrial infrastructure upgrading, and water reuse mandate expansion, while UK grows steadily at 4.2%, emphasizing tight pollution regulations, net-zero policy implementation, and industrial decarbonization initiatives. Japan demonstrates 3.9% growth, anchored by mature market characteristics, technology-focused system upgrades, and operational efficiency optimization.

How is India Leading Global Market Expansion?

India demonstrates the strongest growth potential in the industrial water treatment market with a CAGR of 7.3% through 2035. The country's leadership position stems from rapid industrialization across manufacturing sectors including chemicals, textiles, and pharmaceuticals, severe water scarcity affecting major industrial regions, and strengthening regulatory enforcement under pollution control board mandates driving treatment system adoption.

Growth is concentrated in major industrial clusters and manufacturing zones, including Mumbai, Delhi, Ahmedabad, and Bangalore, where factories are increasingly implementing effluent treatment plants and water recycling systems to comply with Zero Liquid Discharge norms and freshwater allocation restrictions. Distribution channels through engineering procurement construction contractors, technology providers, and turnkey solution suppliers expand treatment infrastructure across industrial facilities and manufacturing complexes.

The country's growing environmental awareness combined with regulatory pressure provides strong momentum for industrial water management investment, including comprehensive adoption across facility scales from small-medium enterprises to large integrated manufacturing plants.

Key market factors:

Water scarcity pressure concentrated in industrial regions and metropolitan areas with declining groundwater levels and surface water availability

Regulatory enforcement expansion through pollution control board inspections and closure threats for non-compliant facilities

Comprehensive Zero Liquid Discharge mandates ecosystem, including textile industry requirements and chemical sector regulations

Technology localization development featuring domestic engineering companies and international partnerships offering cost-competitive solutions

Why is China Emerging as a High-Growth Market?

In major industrial provinces including Jiangsu, Zhejiang, Guangdong, and Shandong, the adoption of industrial water treatment solutions is accelerating across manufacturing facilities and processing plants, driven by aggressive environmental protection policies and strict effluent discharge standards implementation. The market demonstrates strong growth momentum with a CAGR of 6.7% through 2035, linked to comprehensive industrial sector modernization and increasing focus on ecological civilization development principles.

Industrial facilities are implementing advanced treatment technologies and water recycling systems to meet increasingly stringent discharge permits while supporting production expansion requirements. The country's substantial manufacturing base creates ongoing demand for water treatment infrastructure, while government emphasis on green development drives investment in pollution control and resource conservation technologies.

Key development areas:

Industrial expansion modernization leading water treatment adoption with emphasis on chemical industry, electronics manufacturing, and heavy industry sectors

Environmental regulation strengthening through central government inspection campaigns and provincial enforcement mechanisms

Technology advancement integration enabling domestic equipment manufacturing and international technology partnerships

Water resource management emphasis supporting industrial water allocation controls and wastewater reuse requirements

What drives USA’s Market Resilience?

USA’s market expansion is driven by diverse industrial water management priorities, including aging infrastructure replacement in established manufacturing regions and water reuse mandate compliance in water-scarce western states. The country demonstrates steady growth potential with a CAGR of 4.4% through 2035, supported by continuous regulatory evolution from Environmental Protection Agency and state-level water quality boards implementing stricter discharge limits.

Industrial facilities in USA face implementation considerations related to permit compliance complexity and total cost of ownership optimization, requiring comprehensive treatment system design and operational efficiency. Established environmental compliance culture and substantial industrial water consumption averaging 18 billion gallons daily create stable baseline demand for treatment technologies, particularly among chemical manufacturers, power generators, and food processors where regulatory adherence drives primary investment decisions.

Market characteristics:

Regulatory compliance driving and infrastructure modernization showing robust demand with substantial capital investment across industrial sectors

Regional requirements varying between zero liquid discharge mandates in water-scarce regions and conventional treatment approaches in water-abundant areas

Future projections indicate continued growth with emphasis on digital monitoring systems and energy-efficient treatment technologies

Growing emphasis on public-private partnerships and build-operate-transfer models supporting municipal industrial park water infrastructure

How does Germany Demonstrate Circular Economy Leadership?

The industrial water treatment market in Germany leads in sustainable water management based on comprehensive circular economy policies and industrial resource efficiency programs for enhanced environmental performance. The country shows strong potential with a CAGR of 4.6% through 2035, driven by stringent Water Framework Directive implementation and industrial facility commitments to water stewardship in major manufacturing regions, including North Rhine-Westphalia, Bavaria, and Baden-Württemberg.

German industrial operators are adopting advanced treatment technologies through sustainability-driven investments and emphasis on closed-loop water systems for comprehensive resource conservation, particularly in chemical industry clusters and automotive manufacturing facilities demanding proven environmental credentials. Distribution channels through specialized engineering firms and technology providers expand coverage across industrial parks and manufacturing complexes.

Leading market segments:

Circular economy implementation in major industrial sectors requiring water recycling and resource recovery systems

Technology innovation leadership with German engineering companies developing advanced membrane systems and oxidation processes

Strategic collaborations between industrial associations and technology providers advancing water efficiency benchmarks

Focus on energy-water nexus optimization addressing carbon footprint reduction alongside water conservation

What positions UK for Regulatory Compliance Leadership?

In major industrial regions including North West England, Yorkshire, and Scotland, manufacturing facilities are implementing water treatment upgrades through Environment Agency permit requirements and net-zero strategy alignment, with documented compliance investments showing substantial environmental performance improvement through pollution prevention measures.

The market shows steady growth potential with a CAGR of 4.2% through 2035, linked to ongoing industrial decarbonization programs, aging infrastructure replacement needs, and water company discharge consent conditions in regulated industrial zones. Industrial operators are adopting proven treatment technologies with regulatory guidance to ensure discharge compliance while maintaining operational standards demanded by environmental permits and corporate sustainability commitments. The country's established regulatory framework creates ongoing requirements for treatment system optimization that differentiate through reliable performance and comprehensive compliance documentation.

Market development factors:

Net-zero strategy integration providing growth opportunities in energy-efficient treatment systems and renewable energy coupling

How does Japan Show Technology Excellence Leadership?

Japan's industrial water treatment market demonstrates sophisticated characteristics focused on operational efficiency and technology optimization, with documented deployment of advanced automation systems achieving substantial water recovery improvement through precision control across manufacturing facilities.

The country maintains steady growth momentum with a CAGR of 3.9% through 2035, driven by mature market dynamics emphasizing system upgrades and continuous improvement methodologies that align with Japanese manufacturing excellence standards applied to environmental management.

Major industrial regions, including Tokyo-Yokohama, Osaka-Kobe, and Nagoya, showcase advanced adoption of treatment technologies where membrane filtration integrates seamlessly with real-time monitoring systems and comprehensive predictive maintenance programs.

Key market characteristics:

What characterizes Brazil's Market Development?

In major industrial centers including São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, Minas Gerais, and Rio Grande do Sul, the adoption of industrial water treatment solutions is expanding across manufacturing facilities and agro-processing plants, driven by industrial sector growth and increasing environmental compliance enforcement.

The market demonstrates moderate growth potential with a CAGR of 5.6% through 2035, linked to comprehensive regulatory framework development and increasing focus on sustainable industrial practices in major production regions. Brazilian industrial operators are implementing treatment systems and upgrading existing infrastructure to meet state environmental agency requirements while supporting production capacity expansion.

The country's growing industrial base creates ongoing demand for treatment technologies, while water resource management priorities in water-stressed regions drive adoption of recycling systems and efficiency measures.

Key development areas:

Europe Market Split by Country

The industrial water treatment market in Europe is projected to grow from USD 14.2 billion in 2025 to USD 23.1 billion by 2035, registering a CAGR of 5.0% over the forecast period. Germany is expected to maintain its leadership position with a 30.0% market share in 2025, adjusting to 29.5% by 2035, supported by its dominant industrial manufacturing base, comprehensive environmental regulations, and circular economy policy leadership serving major European markets.

France follows with a 19.5% share in 2025, projected to reach 20.0% by 2035, driven by comprehensive Water Framework Directive implementation and industrial sustainability programs in major manufacturing regions requiring advanced treatment solutions. UK holds a 17.0% share in 2025, expected to maintain 17.5% by 2035 through ongoing regulatory compliance mandates and net-zero industrial strategy implementation.

Italy commands a 15.5% share, while Spain accounts for 12.0% in 2025. The rest of Europe is anticipated to gain momentum, expanding its collective share from 6.0% to 6.5% by 2035, attributed to increasing industrial water management adoption in Nordic countries and emerging Eastern European manufacturing sectors implementing modern environmental practices.

Competitive Landscape of the Industrial Water Treatment Market

The industrial water treatment market features approximately 20-30 meaningful players with moderate concentration, where the top three companies control roughly 25-30% of global market share through established technology portfolios, comprehensive service capabilities, and multi-region operational presence. Competition centers on integrated solutions delivery, digital technology integration, and long-term service contracts rather than equipment price competition alone.

Market leaders include Veolia Environnement S.A. with a 9.5% market share, along with Ecolab and Suez, which maintain competitive advantages through vertically integrated offerings spanning water treatment chemicals, equipment systems, and operational services, comprehensive industrial sector expertise, and deep relationships with major manufacturing corporations, creating high credibility among facility managers seeking reliable water management partners.

These companies leverage extensive research and development capabilities and global service networks to defend market positions while expanding into adjacent categories including water-energy nexus solutions and digital water management platforms.

Challengers encompass specialized technology providers including Xylem focusing on equipment and digital solutions, Kurita Water Industries emphasizing chemical treatment and engineering services, and Pentair plc competing through filtration systems and separation technologies. Equipment manufacturers and chemical suppliers, including Kemira, Solenis, and Feralco AB, focus on specific technology areas or chemical formulations, offering differentiated capabilities in membrane systems, specialty chemicals, and application-specific solutions.

Emerging digital water technology companies and modular system providers create competitive pressure through innovative business models and scalable solutions, particularly in high-growth markets including India and Southeast Asia, where decentralized treatment systems and pay-per-use models provide advantages in capital-constrained industrial facilities.

Market dynamics favor companies that combine technology expertise with operational service capabilities addressing complete water management lifecycles from system design through operations, maintenance, and performance optimization. Strategic emphasis on digital transformation, sustainability integration, and outcome-based contracting enables differentiation in increasingly competitive industrial water management segments across developed and emerging markets.

Global Industrial Water Treatment Market — Stakeholder Contribution Framework

Industrial water treatment represents a critical infrastructure category that enables manufacturing facilities and processing plants to achieve regulatory compliance and operational efficiency while addressing water scarcity and environmental sustainability requirements without exclusive freshwater dependency, typically providing comprehensive solutions including advanced filtration achieving high contaminant removal, chemical conditioning preventing equipment damage, and water recycling enabling substantial freshwater reduction compared to once-through water usage alone while ensuring improved environmental performance and comprehensive operational reliability outcomes.

With the market projected to grow from USD 48.0 billion in 2025 to USD 80.5 billion by 2035 at a 5.3% CAGR, these solutions offer compelling advantages for chemical manufacturing applications, water recycling systems, and diverse industrial sectors seeking sustainable water management. Scaling market adoption and technology implementation requires coordinated action across environmental policy, technology development, solution providers, industrial end-users, and financing mechanisms.

How Could Governments Spur Local Development and Adoption?

Environmental Regulation Enforcement: Strengthen discharge standards and compliance monitoring, providing clear permit requirements and supporting enforcement agencies through inspection capacity and technical resources.

Financial Incentive Programs: Implement tax credits for water treatment investments, provide accelerated depreciation for environmental equipment, and establish low-interest financing for small-medium enterprise treatment system adoption.

Technology Development Support: Fund research programs for energy-efficient treatment technologies, support pilot demonstrations of innovative systems, and create technology transfer mechanisms facilitating commercialization.

Water Pricing Reform: Establish volumetric water pricing reflecting scarcity value, implement wastewater discharge fees encouraging source reduction, and create differential tariffs incentivizing water recycling adoption.

Public Infrastructure Investment: Develop industrial park shared treatment facilities, fund common effluent treatment plants, and support public-private partnerships for decentralized treatment systems.

How Could Industry Bodies Support Market Development?

Technical Standards Development: Define standardized performance requirements for industrial water treatment across discharge quality and system reliability, establish universal testing protocols and quality assurance methodologies, and create technology assessment frameworks supporting informed selection.

Best Practice Dissemination: Lead industry guidance on treatment technology selection, operational optimization approaches, and maintenance protocols, emphasizing proven solutions and realistic performance expectations.

Benchmarking Programs: Develop water efficiency metrics for industrial sectors, establish performance benchmarking databases, and create recognition programs incentivizing water stewardship excellence.

Professional Development: Run certification programs for operators, engineers, and facility managers on treatment system operation, troubleshooting procedures, and regulatory compliance across diverse industrial applications.

How Could Technology Providers and Manufacturers Strengthen the Ecosystem?

Integrated Solution Development: Develop comprehensive water management systems combining chemical treatment, physical processes, and membrane technologies with digital monitoring and control optimization.

Performance Guarantee Programs: Provide outcome-based contracting ensuring discharge compliance, water recovery targets, and operational cost commitments that support customer confidence and long-term partnerships.

Digital Platform Integration: Offer advanced monitoring systems, predictive maintenance analytics, and remote operations support that enhance system reliability and optimize performance throughout lifecycles.

Technical Service Excellence: Build comprehensive support capabilities including system design, commissioning assistance, operator training, and ongoing optimization consulting that ensure successful implementation and sustained performance.

How Could Industrial Facilities and Operators Navigate the Market?

Strategic Water Management Planning: Develop comprehensive water audits identifying consumption patterns, waste generation, and treatment requirements for prioritized investment and phased implementation strategies.

Technology Selection Excellence: Conduct thorough evaluations comparing treatment alternatives on total cost of ownership, performance reliability, and operational complexity through pilot testing and reference validation.

Operations Optimization Systems: Implement continuous monitoring programs, establish key performance indicators, and deploy improvement methodologies that maximize treatment efficiency and minimize operational costs.

Sustainability Integration: Align water management with corporate environmental targets, establish transparent reporting systems, and pursue water stewardship certifications supporting stakeholder communication.

How Could Investors and Financial Enablers Unlock Value?

Infrastructure Project Financing: Provide growth capital for technology companies expanding manufacturing capacity and service networks, funding large-scale industrial treatment facility development.

Innovation Investment: Back startups developing breakthrough technologies including low-energy desalination, novel biological processes, and artificial intelligence-driven optimization platforms enhancing market competitiveness.

Project Finance Structures: Finance build-operate-transfer projects for industrial parks, support design-build-operate contracts, and enable long-term service agreements reducing industrial facility capital requirements.

Asset Management: Support water infrastructure funds investing in industrial treatment facilities, enable operational efficiency improvements, and develop secondary markets for proven treatment systems.

name: Delta Airlines
title: Largest Flight Attendant Union In The U.S. Faces Computer Fraud Allegations In Ongoing ... - PYOK
description:
A federal judge has allowed a counterclaim accusing the largest flight attendant union in the United States of conspiracy to commit computer fraud to proceed following months of legal wrangling in a Utah District Court.
In October 2023, the AFA sued SkyWest over accusations of serious labor law violations over its funding of the SkyWest Inflight Association, or SIA for short.
Representing more than 50,000 flight attendants, the Association of Flight Attendants is by far the largest crew member union in the United States.
Since 2019, SkyWest has funded an independent staff association for its crew members known as the SkyWest Inflight Association (SIA).
The judge did, however, allow part of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act counterclaim to proceed – notably that of conspiracy.
text:
A federal judge has allowed a counterclaim accusing the largest flight attendant union in the United States of conspiracy to commit computer fraud to proceed following months of legal wrangling in a Utah District Court.

The contentious allegations were made against the Association of Flight Attendants (AFA-CWA) by a staff association representing crew members at the major regional carrier SkyWest, which provides services to the likes of Alaska Airlines, Delta, and United Airlines.

In October 2023, the AFA sued SkyWest over accusations of serious labor law violations over its funding of the SkyWest Inflight Association, or SIA for short. In response, SIA filed a slew of serious counterclaims against the AFA.

How Did The Dispute Start In The First Place?

Representing more than 50,000 flight attendants, the Association of Flight Attendants is by far the largest crew member union in the United States. For years, it has tried but failed to become the official union of around 4,600 flight attendants at the Utah-based regional carrier SkyWest.

Since 2019, SkyWest has funded an independent staff association for its crew members known as the SkyWest Inflight Association (SIA).

SIA is the only body allowed to negotiate with SkyWest management over various issues like pay, conditions, and internal policies, although the AFA has questioned SIA’s true independence or ability to negotiate on behalf of SkyWest flight attendants.

A dispute between the AFA, SIA, and SkyWest came to a head in 2023 when the airline sacked two veteran crew members after they exposed what they claimed were serious security flaws with an internal election held by SIA.

AFA Accused Of Computer Fraud Conspiracy

In April 2023, one of the flight attendants who was later terminated discovered that SIA’s supposed secure website could be easily manipulated by changing the URL. This then allowed access to confidential information like crew member names, their ID numbers, and voting credentials for SIA elections.

The crew member shared this information with a coworker and an AFA representative. But rather than also immediately reporting the vulnerability to SIA, the trio allegedly sat on this information, according to SIA.

More than that, SIA claims the three hatched a plan to quietly access the vulnerability each month, and AFA’s agent allegedly instructed one of the crew members to “quietly download” information from the SIA secure website each month, the association claimed.

This continued until August 2023, when the SIA held internal elections. After votes had already been cast, another crew member produced a video explaining the vulnerability, which ultimately led to the ballot being abandoned.

Judge Permits Computer Fraud Conspiracy Counterclaim To Proceed

After the AFA sued SkyWest for terminating the crew members who had exposed the security vulnerability, SIA made a slew of counterclaims against the AFA, including violations of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act.

In total, the SIA made eight counterclaims:

Violations of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act

Claims under the Stored Communications Act

Utah Computer Abuse and Data Recovery Act

Breach of Contract against one of the crew members

Conversion (civil theft of property)

Trespass to Chattels

Civil Conspiracy

Tortious Interference with Contract

The AFA then moved to have six of these counterclaims dismissed. Earlier this week, District Judge David Barlow made his ruling.

Judge Barlow ruled that many of SIA’s counterclaims should be dismissed, including a standalone civil conspiracy claim.

The judge did, however, allow part of the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act counterclaim to proceed – notably that of conspiracy.

Lawsuit Began In October 2023 When Skywest Was Accused Of ‘Extraordinary Violations’ of Labor Law

The AFA filed its suit against SkyWest in October 2023 over what it described as “extraordinary violations” of labor law. The lawsuit almost immediately followed SkyWest’s decision to terminate the two flight attendants who exposed the security vulnerability in SIA’s secure website.

The ongoing lawsuit alleges that Skywest violated the Railway Labor Act in several areas, including funding SIA and terminating Price and Grange without a mechanism for arbitration.

Department of Labor Is Also Suing SkyWest’s Flight Attendant Association

Last August, the Department of Labor filed a seperate lawsuit against SIA over the way it ran its local elections in 2023.

The lawsuit alleged that a former executive officer of SIA and potentially several other members of the association cast ballots for at least 300 members – something that came to light when members went to vote only to find that their ballots had already been cast.

When SIA carried out a rerun of the election, it disqualified two nominees because they had allegedly shown disloyalty to the association over their support for the AFA.

Bottom Line

Although very narrow in its scope, a district judge has ruled that a counterclaim can continue against an AFA agent for alleged computer fraud conspiracy in connection with a secure website used by the SkyWest staff association.

name: J&J
title: Johnson's Wounded Knee Memorial Bill Passes U.S. Senate
description:
Washington, D.C. – Today, the Wounded Knee Sacred Site and Memorial Act, introduced by U.S. Representative Dusty Johnson (R-S.D.
“Nearly 135 years after hundreds of lives were lost in the Wounded Knee Massacre, the time is now here to properly memorialize the lost and preserve the land,” said Johnson.
“It is now poised to become an Act of Congress: an important Act that will preserve the memory of the Wounded Knee Massacre and the legacy and sacrifice of our ancestors.
Significantly, it also promotes tribal self-determination and allows us to protect our Wounded Knee site in perpetuity.
Wounded Knee Massacre Background: In the late 1880s, a movement called the Ghost Dance swept across the nation.
text:
Washington, D.C. – Today, the Wounded Knee Sacred Site and Memorial Act, introduced by U.S. Representative Dusty Johnson (R-S.D.), passed the United States Senate by unanimous consent. The bill now heads to the president’s desk.

“Nearly 135 years after hundreds of lives were lost in the Wounded Knee Massacre, the time is now here to properly memorialize the lost and preserve the land,” said Johnson. “I look forward to seeing the president sign this into law to ensure the land remains sacred for generations to come.”

“We thank the Senators Thune and Rounds and Congressman Dusty Johnson for their leadership and support in helping us protect our sacred site through the passage of the Wounded Knee Massacre Memorial and Sacred Site Act,” said Ryman LeBeau, Chairman, Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe. “The U.S. Cavalry shot at and murdered more than 350 unarmed Lakota babies, girls, boys, women, men, and elders at Wounded Knee on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. The U.S. Cavalry stopped our people out on the high plains as they were seeking peace, surrounded them with guns and cannons, disarmed them, opened fire, and murdered them. Today, we stand to acknowledge the atrocities committed against the Lakota people to continue to heal, to protect, to educate, and most importantly, to ensure that we never forget the Wounded Knee Massacre of 1890.”

“On behalf of the Oglala Sioux Tribe, I am pleased that today the Senate passed the Wounded Knee Massacre site bill, a bill that passed the House earlier this year,” said Frank Star Comes Out, President, Oglala Sioux Tribe. “It is now poised to become an Act of Congress: an important Act that will preserve the memory of the Wounded Knee Massacre and the legacy and sacrifice of our ancestors. Significantly, it also promotes tribal self-determination and allows us to protect our Wounded Knee site in perpetuity. We thank Representative Dusty Johnson as well as Senator Rounds and Majority Leader Thune for getting this bill through both chambers of Congress. It is fitting that this action comes as we prepare to commemorate the 135th anniversary of the Wounded Knee Massacre on December 29th.”

After months of working in coordination with the Oglala Sioux Tribe and Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe, Johnson introduced the legislation last Congress, which passed the House unanimously but was not voted on by the U.S. Senate. Johnson reintroduced the bill in January 2025 and it passed the House later that month.

The identical Senate companion bill is led by U.S. Senators Mike Rounds (R-S.D.) and John Thune (R-S.D.).

Wounded Knee Massacre Background:

In the late 1880s, a movement called the Ghost Dance swept across the nation. Indians believed that this dance would give stolen land back to the Indians, bringing about a renewal of Native society. Indians would join together, wearing shirts they believed would protect them from bullets, to dance for this renewal, all at the protest of the federal government.

On December 29, 1890, a group of Lakota Indians led by Chief Spotted Elk had made camp near Wounded Knee Creek on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota. There, U.S. Army 7th Calvary troops were sent to disarm the Lakota. A struggle occurred between the U.S. Army and some of Chief Spotted Elk’s band – a majority of which consisted of women and children. A shot rang out, and the U.S. Army opened fire on the largely unarmed group, massacring an estimated up to 350-375 Lakota Indians. Twenty-five U.S. soldiers also died.

name: Barclays
title: Kate Waugh: British triathlete crowned world champion after winning T100 final in Qatar - BBC Sport
description:
Britain's Kate Waugh came through a three-way battle to win the T100 Triathlon World Championship final in Qatar.
It sealed a first ever world title in the sport for the 26-year-old.
Derron had started the day just six points behind Waugh, with Charles-Barclay a further three points back, but neither could match Waugh's pace in the closing stages as she pulled in front.
However, the Gateshead-born triathlete was exhausted towards the end of the run and had to walk the final stretch before she collapsed to her knees.
That was the most dramatic way to win the world title."
text:
Britain's Kate Waugh came through a three-way battle to win the T100 Triathlon World Championship final in Qatar.

It sealed a first ever world title in the sport for the 26-year-old.

Waugh had been top of the standings heading into event and finished clear of rivals Julie Derron of Switzerland and fellow Briton Lucy Charles-Barclay, who came third and fifth respectively.

Derron had started the day just six points behind Waugh, with Charles-Barclay a further three points back, but neither could match Waugh's pace in the closing stages as she pulled in front.

However, the Gateshead-born triathlete was exhausted towards the end of the run and had to walk the final stretch before she collapsed to her knees.

"I've always been a bit of a drama queen, so perhaps that was the best way to win it I guess," said Waugh, whose final points tally of 183 was 20 more than Derron with Charles-Barclay on 152.

"I'm completely overwhelmed with emotion right now. I do not want to see those finish line photos. That was the most dramatic way to win the world title."

name: Instacart
title: Instacart Was Charging Wildly Diverging Prices for Different Shoppers, an Investigation ...
description:
The practice, known as surveillance pricing, appears to go back to Instacart's 2022 acquisition of Eversight, an AI pricing company.
With surveillance pricing, algorithms set individualized prices based on your customer data, often without your knowledge.
"These tests are not dynamic pricing—prices never change in real-time, including in response to supply and demand," an Instacart spokesperson told Investopedia.
"And with AI making surveillance pricing easier and faster, it’s only going to get worse."
California, Colorado and Pennsylvania are also considering legislation that goes beyond New York’s notification requirement, banning surveillance pricing outright for certain retailers.
text:
The U.S. government may have minted the last penny last month, but Instacart's algorithms are still fighting for every last cent.

While shoppers have grown accustomed to prices ending in .99—a psychological trick as old as the cash register—Instacart (CART) users like me see something different: $4.17 for eggs, $17.37 for Nature Valley bars, $11.43 for basil pesto. The company's pricing shifts seemingly every time you log in, with price changes down to the penny.

A major investigation published this week suggests just how far Instacart's pricing precision has been taken. Consumer Reports and Groundwork Collaborative found that Instacart has been running AI-powered pricing experiments on millions of shoppers, charging customers different prices for identical items at the same stores, sometimes as much as 23% extra.

I reviewed a year's worth of my own Costco Wholesale (COST) orders through Instacart and found the same pattern—double-digit price swings on items I buy regularly, with no obvious explanation. (More on that below)

What the Investigation Found

CR and Groundwork Collaborative recruited 437 volunteers across four cities to shop on Instacart for identical items at the same stores simultaneously. Three-quarters of the products had different prices for each user. The average shopping basket varied by about 7%—a difference that CR estimated could cost a family about $1,200 a year.

The retailers affected included Costco, Kroger (KR), Target (TGT), Safeway, Albertsons (ACI) and Sprouts (SFM).

The practice, known as surveillance pricing, appears to go back to Instacart's 2022 acquisition of Eversight, an AI pricing company. In the company's 2023 shareholder letter, Instacart described one of its tools, "smart rounding," as "a machine learning-driven tool that helps retailers improve price perception and drive incremental sales."

With surveillance pricing, algorithms set individualized prices based on your customer data, often without your knowledge. Unlike a price tag or a coupon, it's invisible—two people can see different prices for the same item simultaneously and not know it.

It's also tricky for outside analysts to prove it's being used, but the CR investigators caught a lucky break. Costco accidentally forwarded an internal Instacart email confirming that "smart rounding" experiments were underway between the companies. After its investigation was published, Instacart said it had stopped running pricing experiments at both Costco and Target.

But Instacart has stopped short of saying it was using algorithms based on specific individuals. "These tests are not dynamic pricing—prices never change in real-time, including in response to supply and demand," an Instacart spokesperson told Investopedia. "The tests are never based on personal or behavioral characteristics—they are completely randomized."

But a disclosure Instacart shows its New York customers tells a different story. Under the state's Algorithmic Pricing Disclosure Act, which took effect Nov. 10, the company must tell its users if it engages in the practice. As such, its app notifies New York users that "certain prices and/or fees may vary based on randomized tests," "we use personal information (such as delivery address) to calculate fees, and "this price was set by an algorithm using your personal data."

What I Found in My Own Orders

My family orders from Costco through Instacart almost every other week, so I pulled a year of receipts to see whether the same kinds of price swings showed up in my own history.

They did: The price I paid for Kirkland thick-sliced bacon ranged from $14.75 to $17.59, a 19% jump for the same product. Kerrygold butter swung even more, from $11.58 to $17.58, a 52% difference. Even a pantry staple like Kirkland basil pesto moved between $10.37 and $11.43.

Not everything shifted. Bananas stayed anchored at $1.63–$1.64 all year; Costco's famed $4.99 rotisserie chicken rang up as $5.46 throughout the year on Instacart with its extra fee. But the items with the biggest swings were the same as those CR flagged: branded staples and higher-margin products such as eggs, olive oil and blueberries.

Price changes over time are normal—after all, grocery prices rose about 2.7% over the past year. But the CR investigation worked by having volunteers shop simultaneously, exposing how people were getting different prices for the same goods as the same time. Like other customers, I can't replicate that just with my own receipts and reviewing prices over time at my local store, which makes it almost impossible to separate ordinary price changes from algorithmic testing.

And that’s the point: Instacart is marketed as a convenience. Few people have the time or the data-wrangling skills to untangle whether a price hike is a seasonal shift or part of an AI-driven experiment running quietly in the background.

How Instacart Explains Its Pricing

You have to dig for the scant details Instacart provides on the prices it adds to your bill beyond its service fee for each delivery and your annual membership costs for both Costco and Instacart. At the top of each retailer’s Instacart page, there’s a small link called “Pricing & Fees.” Clicking through pulls up a brief disclosure: retailers may charge more on Instacart, and a flat percentage markup is added to cover Instacart’s service.

What the policy doesn’t say is how big that markup is or who sets it. When journalists have asked where the prices come from when you buy items from Costco through Instacart, the companies have pointed the finger at each other. Instacart has said, "each of our retail partners sets the prices." Costco has said the opposite: "Pricing above and beyond our walk-in warehouse price is set by Instacart."

Instacart’s own terms of service add another wrinkle, noting that the company may vary fees based on demand, order attributes or other factors—language that reads very differently after the investigation into its algorithmic pricing experiments.

What's Next for Surveillance Pricing

Lawmakers are taking notice. This week, Senator Ruben Gallego (D-AZ) introduced the "One Fair Price Act," which would ban companies from charging customers different prices based on their personal data.

“Experimenting with people’s hard-earned money to see just how much you can get them to pay for food for their family isn’t fair pricing," Jane Garza, Gallego’s spokesperson, told Investopedia. "And with AI making surveillance pricing easier and faster, it’s only going to get worse."

California, Colorado and Pennsylvania are also considering legislation that goes beyond New York’s notification requirement, banning surveillance pricing outright for certain retailers. For now, shoppers in the other 49 states are left to read the fine print—and wonder what it's not telling them.

name: OpenAI
title: Oracle stock falls as OpenAI data center completion pushed to 2028 - Investing.com
description:
Investing.com -- stock fell 5% on Friday following a Bloomberg report that the company has delayed the completion of data centers for OpenAI to 2028, a year later than initially planned.
According to people familiar with the project who requested anonymity, the postponement is mainly due to labor and material shortages.
Shares pared losses to 4% by 2 pm after Oracle issued a statement addressing the report.
Despite the reported delays, the timeline for these U.S. projects remains ambitious as they are set to become some of the largest data centers globally.
Oracle’s stock movement contributed to weakness in the technology sector, which has been weighing on major indices as investors reassess valuations in the AI space.
text:
Investing.com -- stock fell 5% on Friday following a Bloomberg report that the company has delayed the completion of data centers for OpenAI to 2028, a year later than initially planned.

According to people familiar with the project who requested anonymity, the postponement is mainly due to labor and material shortages. Oracle has been working to fulfill a $300 billion contract to provide computing power for training and running OpenAI’s models since signing the agreement this summer.

Shares pared losses to 4% by 2 pm after Oracle issued a statement addressing the report. "There have been no delays to any sites required to meet our contractual commitments, and all milestones remain on track," a company spokesperson said, adding that "site selection and delivery timelines were established in close coordination with OpenAI."

Despite the reported delays, the timeline for these U.S. projects remains ambitious as they are set to become some of the largest data centers globally.

The decline extends Oracle’s recent downward trend, coming just a day after its shares closed sharply lower following softer-than-expected quarterly results.

The broader market also struggled on Friday, with the S&P 500 falling 1.25% and the Nasdaq dropping 2%. latest results added to growing concerns about a potential bubble in artificial intelligence stocks, compounding worries already sparked by Oracle’s disappointing performance.

Oracle’s stock movement contributed to weakness in the technology sector, which has been weighing on major indices as investors reassess valuations in the AI space.

description:
Key Takeaways Jefferies maintains Buy rating for Ralph Lauren (RL, Financial) and raises price target to $425.
On December 12, 2025, Jefferies analyst Ashley Helgans maintained a Buy rating for Ralph Lauren (RL) while raising the price target from $385 to $425.
The consistent upward adjustments in price targets by various analysts suggest a positive outlook for Ralph Lauren (RL) in the market.
Founded by designer Ralph Lauren (current executive chairman and chief creative officer) in 1967 in New York City, Ralph Lauren Corp. designs, markets, and distributes lifestyle merchandise in North America, Europe, and Asia.
The company's brands include Ralph Lauren Collection, Polo Ralph Lauren, and Lauren Ralph Lauren.
text:
Key Takeaways

Jefferies maintains Buy rating for Ralph Lauren (RL, Financial) and raises price target to $425.

Recent analyst activities show a pattern of raised price targets for RL.

On December 12, 2025, Jefferies analyst Ashley Helgans maintained a Buy rating for Ralph Lauren (RL) while raising the price target from $385 to $425. This adjustment reflects a 10.39% increase in the price target, indicating confidence in the stock's potential growth.

Historical Ratings

December 10, 2025: Guggenheim initiated coverage on Ralph Lauren (RL, Financial) with a Neutral rating.

December 3, 2025: Wells Fargo maintained an Overweight rating and raised the price target from $345 to $385, marking an 11.59% increase.

November 7, 2025: Telsey Advisory Group maintained an Outperform rating, raising the price target from $350 to $365, up by 4.29%.

November 7, 2025: Evercore ISI Group maintained an Outperform rating and increased the price target from $375 to $385, an increase of 2.67%.

November 7, 2025: Barclays maintained an Overweight rating, raising the price target from $352 to $358, a 1.70% increase.

The consistent upward adjustments in price targets by various analysts suggest a positive outlook for Ralph Lauren (RL) in the market. Investors may find these insights helpful in understanding the current analyst sentiment surrounding this stock.

Founded by designer Ralph Lauren (current executive chairman and chief creative officer) in 1967 in New York City, Ralph Lauren Corp. designs, markets, and distributes lifestyle merchandise in North America, Europe, and Asia. Best known for its iconic polo shirts, its products also include other types of apparel, footwear, eyewear, jewelry, handbags, home goods, and fragrances. The company's brands include Ralph Lauren Collection, Polo Ralph Lauren, and Lauren Ralph Lauren. Distribution channels for Ralph Lauren include wholesale (department stores and specialty stores), retail (company-owned retail stores and e-commerce), and licensing.

Wall Street Analysts Forecast

Based on the one-year price targets offered by 15 analysts, the average target price for Ralph Lauren Corp (RL, Financial) is $366.82 with a high estimate of $435.00 and a low estimate of $196.54. The average target implies an downside of 1.34% from the current price of $371.79. More detailed estimate data can be found on the Ralph Lauren Corp (RL) Forecast page.

Based on the consensus recommendation from 20 brokerage firms, Ralph Lauren Corp's (RL, Financial) average brokerage recommendation is currently 2.0, indicating "Outperform" status. The rating scale ranges from 1 to 5, where 1 signifies Strong Buy, and 5 denotes Sell.

name: Kraft Heinz
title: Kellanova Stock Is No More. Should Consumer Packaged Goods Fans Buy Shares ... - Barchart.com
description:
Kellanova, a huge consumer packaged goods company, has been acquired by Mars, and K stock is expected to be delisted soon, as its acquisition closed yesterday, Dec. 11.
Consequently, the former owners of K stock may be thinking of looking to buy Kraft Heinz (KHC), which is the closest publicly traded alternative to Kellanova.
About KHC Stock Kraft Heinz, as its name indicates, owns and markets the Kraft and Heinz brands.
Obviously, if Berkshire sells a sizeable amount of its shares, KHC stock is likely to sink meaningfully.
The most attractive aspect of KHC stock is its high dividend yield, which is currently about 6.5%.
text:
Kellanova, a huge consumer packaged goods company, has been acquired by Mars, and K stock is expected to be delisted soon, as its acquisition closed yesterday, Dec. 11. Consequently, the former owners of K stock may be thinking of looking to buy Kraft Heinz (KHC), which is the closest publicly traded alternative to Kellanova.

About KHC Stock

Kraft Heinz, as its name indicates, owns and markets the Kraft and Heinz brands. It also has many other consumer packaged food brands, such as Oscar Mayer, Jell-O, and Philadelphia Cream Cheese. The company has a market capitalization of $28.7 billion.

In the third quarter, KHC's sales dropped slightly to $6.237 billion from $6.383 billion during the same period a year earlier. However, its operating cash flow did increase to $3.09 billion from $2.8 billion.

In September, the company announced that it would split itself “into two scaled, focused companies.” One firm will include the Heinz, Philadelphia, and Kraft Mac & Cheese brands, “with approximately 75% of (its) net sales coming from sauces, spreads and seasonings.” The other spun-off company will feature the Oscar Mayer, Kraft Singles, and Lunchables brands. In 2024, the two firms generated EBITDA, excluding some items, of about $4 billion and roughly $2.3 billion, respectively.

According to KHC, the move will allow the two spun-off entities to be more focused and efficient.

Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) (BRK.B) owned 27.5% of KHC as of September. Also in September, CNBC reported that KHC had lost over two-thirds of its value since the merger that formed Kraft Heinz in 2015, which Berkshire helped engineer, was finalized.

The Threats Facing KHC Stock

In an interview with CNBC in September, Buffett would not dismiss the possibility of Berkshire selling part of its stake or its entire stake in the firm. Obviously, if Berkshire sells a sizeable amount of its shares, KHC stock is likely to sink meaningfully.

The most attractive aspect of KHC stock is its high dividend yield, which is currently about 6.5%. But in the press release announcing the split, KHC did not 100% commit to maintaining the yield. “In aggregate, the current dividend level is expected to be maintained,” the firm stated.

CNBC noted that “health-conscious consumers” bought fewer of KHC's products, which tend to feature unhealthy items like processed cheeses, processed meats, and sizeable amounts of sugar, in the years following the merger. With 85% of consumers reportedly worrying about the healthiness of the food and beverage items that they buy, according to recent research, that issue may have intensified since the merger and certainly hasn't faded at all. Further, the year-over-year (YoY) decline of the firm's revenue in Q3 indicates that this issue may still be negatively impacting its growth.

And in a related development, KHC, at the urging of the U.S. government, announced in June that it would remove "Food, Drug & Cosmetic (FD&C) colors" from all of its products “before the end of 2027.” Although KHC stated that almost 90% of its products “by net sales” in America no longer have FD&C colors, it's possible that this change will have a material, negative impact on the company's financial results.

No Major Positive Catalysts

It's true that in recent years, some spun-off stocks, such as GE Vernova (GEV) and Solventum (SOLV), have performed extremely well. But the spun-off stocks that delivered great results for investors tended to have had extremely powerful positive catalysts.

Conversely, the only potential positive catalyst that I see for KHC is the increased focus and efficiency cited by the company following the merger. But that's not a very tangible catalyst, and even Buffett said he does not believe that the breakup will address the issues that KHC is facing. Others were also dubious about the efficacy of the transaction, with, for example, Yahoo Finance executive editor Brian Sozzi stating that “More marketing support isn't some form of elixir.”
